            super("text",bean,property);
        }
    }
    
    public class ComboFieldAdapter extends ComponentAdapterByAnnotationForBeanProperty<Order>
    {
        String m_parkedText;
        public ComboFieldAdapter(Order bean,String property)
        { 
            super("text",bean,property);
        }
        @Override
        /* This is important! The Adapter by default uses the property type of the
         * referenced property (here: "customer"). But you override: the control is
         * served with String-instances - not with Customer-instances. */
        public Class getPropertyType() 
        { 
            return String.class; 
        }
        @Override
        /* Convert referecned "Customer" into "String", */
        public Object getPropertyValue()
        {
            Customer c = (Customer)super.getPropertyValue();
            if (c == null)
                return m_parkedText;
            else
                return c.toString();
        }
        @Override
        /* Convert String input into Customer. */
        public void setPropertyValue(Object value)
        {
            m_parkedText = null;
            if (value == null)
            {
                super.setPropertyValue(value);
            }
            else
            {
                String s = value.toString();
                Customer c = lookupCustomer(s);
                super.setPropertyValue(c);
                if (c == null)
                    m_parkedText = s;
            }
        }
        @ComponentAttribute
        public String getBgpaint()
        {
            if (m_parkedText != null)
                return "error()";
            else
                return null;
        }
        @Override
        public void onAction(ActionEvent event)
        { 
            if (event instanceof BaseActionEventValueHelp)
            {
                IdTextSelection idts = IdTextSelection.createInstance();
                List<Customer> cs = findCustomers();
                for (Customer c: cs)
                    idts.addLine(c.getCustomerId(),c.toString());
                idts.setCallBack(new ISetId()
                {
                    @Override
                    public void setId(String id)
                    { 
                        setPropertyValue(id);
                    }
                });
            }
        }
        /* This methods should be implemented in the business logic in real life scenarios! */ 
        private Customer lookupCustomer(String s)
        {
            List<Customer> cs = findCustomers();
            for (Customer c: cs)
            {
                if (c.getCustomerId().equals(s))
                    return c;
            }
            return null;
        }
        /* This methods should be implemented in the business logic in real life scenarios! */ 
        private List<Customer> findCustomers()
        {
            List<Customer> result = new ArrayList<Customer>();
            for (int i=0; i<100; i++)
            {
                Customer c = new Customer();
                c.setCustomerId((4700+i)+"");
                c.setCustomerName("Customer " + c.getCustomerId());
                result.add(c);
            }
            return result;
        }
    }
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    Order m_order;
    FieldAdapter m_orderIdAdapter;
    FieldAdapter m_orderCommentAdapter;
    ComboFieldAdapter m_customerAdapter;
    String m_resultOutput;

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoCombofieldBeanReference(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);
        m_order = new Order();
        m_customerAdapter = new ComboFieldAdapter(m_order,"customer");
        m_orderIdAdapter = new FieldAdapter(m_order,"orderId");
        m_orderCommentAdapter = new FieldAdapter(m_order,"orderComment");
    }

    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/democombofieldbeanreference.xml"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoCombofieldBeanReference}"; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public Order getOrder() { return m_order; }
    public ComboFieldAdapter getCustomerAdapter() { return m_customerAdapter; }
    public FieldAdapter getOrderIdAdapter() { return m_orderIdAdapter; } 
    public FieldAdapter getOrderCommentAdapter() { return m_orderCommentAdapter; } 
    
    public String getResultOutput() { return m_resultOutput; }
    public void setResultOutput(String value) { this.m_resultOutput = value; }

    public void onOutputAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
        sb.append(  "Id        : " + m_order.getOrderId());
        sb.append("\nCustomer  : " + m_order.getCustomer());
        sb.append("\nComment   : " + m_order.getOrderComment());
        m_resultOutput = sb.toString();
    }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // private usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
}

Long Operations

Progress info

The new server side API "BlockerInfo.sendProgressToClient(...)" allows to send progress messages to the client directly during application processing.

Internally the client opens up a websocket connection to the server that is responsible for transferring progress messages back to the client - without using the "big communication round trip".

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" beanbinding="#{d.DemoBlockerInfo}" />
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_2" objectbinding="#{d.DemoBlockerInfo}" rowdistance="10" >
<t:row id="g_3" >
<t:label id="g_4" stylevariant="ccbig" text="How to make users angry" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_5" >
<t:textpane id="g_6" text="During the application processing on server side the client is blocked for interaction. If this takes more than some seconds then the user sees some &#34;wait icon&#34; - and gest angry because there is no information about what&#39;s going on..." width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_7" >
<t:button id="g_8" actionListener="#{d.DemoBlockerInfo.onLongAngryAction}" text="Start long lasting operation (10 secs)" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_9" height="50" />
<t:row id="g_10" >
<t:label id="g_11" stylevariant="ccbig" text="It&#39;s so simple to inform your users - ...now!" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_12" >
<t:textpane id="g_13" text="Up to now (20201221) you had to outsource your application processing in some own processing thread and then had to use e.g. some websocket long polling to decouple the application processing from the UI processing. Now it is much (muchchchchch!) easier! From the original processing thread you simple can send signals to the client about the progress of the processing." width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_14" >
<t:button id="g_15" actionListener="#{d.DemoBlockerInfo.onLongAction}" text="Start long lasting operation (10 secs)" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.BlockerInfo;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.Statusbar;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoBlockerInfo}")

public class DemoBlockerInfo
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoBlockerInfo(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
    }

    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/demoblockerinfo.jsp"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoBlockerInfo}"; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public void onLongAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        try
        {
            for (int i=0; i<100; i++)
            {
                Thread.sleep(100);
                BlockerInfo.sendProgressToClient("Processing step " + (i+1),i+1);
            }
        }
        catch (Throwable t)
        {
            Statusbar.outputError(t.toString());
        }
    }

    public void onLongAngryAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        try
        {
            Thread.sleep(10000);
        }
        catch (Throwable t)
        {
            Statusbar.outputError(t.toString());
        }
    }

    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // private usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
}

Startup and progress info

Before starting some long operation on server side it is a good idea to inform the user about what happens inside this long operation.

A nice component to use for this purpose is the component CALLSERVERONTRIGGER.

The component gets triggered by some server side Trigger-instance - and then calls the server exactly one time. The actual starting of the long operation is done in two steps as consequence:

1. showing the user what will be done
2. actual processing of the long operation

Step 2 is started "through the client".

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" beanbinding="#{d.DemoLongOperationWithInfo}" >
<t:callserverontrigger id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoLongOperationWithInfo.onButton2ExecuteAction}" trigger="#{d.DemoLongOperationWithInfo.executeTrigger}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" objectbinding="#{d.DemoLongOperationWithInfo}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:button id="g_5" actionListener="#{d.DemoLongOperationWithInfo.onButton1Action}" text="Start long operation - default" width="250#" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_6" >
<t:textpane id="g_7" text="The processing on server side is started without telling the user what internally will be executed." width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_8" height="50" />
<t:row id="g_9" >
<t:button id="g_10" actionListener="#{d.DemoLongOperationWithInfo.onButton2Action}" text="Start long operation - with info" width="250+" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_11" >
<t:textpane id="g_12" text="The processing on server side is started with explicitly telling the users the detail of the operation before." width="100%" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.BlockerInfo;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.ModalPopup;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.Statusbar;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoLongOperationWithInfo}")

public class DemoLongOperationWithInfo
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // inner classes
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    Trigger m_executeTrigger = new Trigger();
    DemoLongOperationWithInfoPopup m_infoPopup = null;
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoLongOperationWithInfo(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
    }

    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/demolongoperationwithinfo.jsp"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoLongOperationWithInfo}"; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public void onButton1Action(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        processItems();
    }

    public Trigger getExecuteTrigger() { return m_executeTrigger; }

    /*
     * This is the method that is called by the button: it opens
     * a popup and triggers the next processing through the client
     */
    public void onButton2Action(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_infoPopup = new DemoLongOperationWithInfoPopup();
        m_infoPopup.setNumberOfItems(100);
        ModalPopup p = openModalPopup(m_infoPopup,"Processing items",0,0,null);
        p.setLeftTopReferenceCentered();
        p.setTop(-200);
        p.setUndecorated(true);
        m_executeTrigger.trigger();
    }

    /**
     * This is the method that is called by the CALLSERVERONTRIGGER component.
     * This method starts the actual processing - and closes the info popup
     * afterwards.
     */
    public void onButton2ExecuteAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        processItems();
        closePopup(m_infoPopup);
    }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // private usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    private void processItems()
    {
        for (int i=0; i<100; i++)
        {
            try { Thread.sleep(40); } catch (Throwable t) {}
            BlockerInfo.sendProgressToClient("Processing item " + i,(i+1));
        }
        Statusbar.outputSuccess("Finished!");
    }
}

Separate thread

Using a WEBSOCKETPOLLING component is the easiest and most efficient way to set up some processing, in which events from the server side are published to the client.

Imaging the WEBSOCKETPOLLING component to be an invisible button, which always activates its actionListener once a server side event occurs. The connection between the "button" and the server side event is a WebSocket connection.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:websocketpolling id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling.onWebSocketAction}" duration="100" websocketurl="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling.webSocketUrl}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" objectbinding="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling}">
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:label id="g_5" text="URL" width="100" />
<t:label id="g_6" cutwidth="true" text="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling.webSocketUrl}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_7" >
<t:coldistance id="g_8" width="100" />
<t:button id="g_9" actionListener="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling.onStopAction}" text="Stop thread processing" />
<t:coldistance id="g_10" width="5" />
<t:button id="g_11" actionListener="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling.onRestartAction}" text="Restart thread processing" width="100+" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_12" >
<t:textarea id="g_13" height="100%" text="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling.protocol}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.polling.LongPollingMgr;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.polling.websocket.DefaultLongPollingWebSocket;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;
import org.eclnt.workplace.WorkpageDefaultLifecycleListener;
import org.eclnt.workplace.WorkpageDispatchedPageBean;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling}")

public class DemoWebSocketPolling
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // inner classes
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    /**
     * This is some server side "event producing thread". 
     */
    public class MyThread extends Thread
    {
        boolean i_threadStop = false;
        @Override
        public void run()
        {
            for (int i=0; i<100; i++)
            {
                try { Thread.sleep(500); } catch (Throwable t) {}
                if (i_threadStop == true) break;
                m_counter++;
                // waking up == sending an event to the client side
                m_longPollingWebSocket.wakeup(true);
            }
            if (m_thread == this) m_thread = null;
        }
    }
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    /**
     * Server side part of the web socket management.
     */
    DefaultLongPollingWebSocket m_longPollingWebSocket;
    
    MyThread m_thread;
    int m_counter = 0;
    String m_protocol = "Protocol:\n";

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoWebSocketPolling(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
        // first creat the web socket part - then register!
        m_longPollingWebSocket = new DefaultLongPollingWebSocket();
        LongPollingMgr.add(m_longPollingWebSocket);
        // if registering something you have to de-register. In this example: de-registration
        // is done when closing the workpage in the workplace. BUT: there may be other, better
        // points of de-registration in your scenario.
        getWorkpage().addLifecycleListener(new WorkpageDefaultLifecycleListener()
        {
            @Override
            public void reactOnDestroyed()
            {
                if (m_thread != null)
                    m_thread.i_threadStop = true;
                LongPollingMgr.remove(m_longPollingWebSocket);
            }
        });
        m_thread = new MyThread();
        m_thread.start();
    }

    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/demowebsocketpolling.jsp"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling}"; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    /**
     * The URL for the web socket is passed back by the {@link DefaultLongPollingWebSocket} instance.
     */
    public String getWebSocketUrl() { return m_longPollingWebSocket.getURL(); }
    
    public String getProtocol() { return m_protocol; }
    public void setProtocol(String value) { this.m_protocol = value; }

    /**
     * This is the actionListener of the WEBSOCKETPOLLING component. The function
     * is called every time an event is communicated to the client side via web socket.
     */
    public void onWebSocketAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_protocol += "\nCurrent counter: " + m_counter; 
    }

    public void onStopAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (m_thread != null)
            m_thread.i_threadStop = true;
        m_thread = null;
    }

    public void onRestartAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (m_thread != null)
            return;
        m_thread = new MyThread();
        m_thread.start();
    }
}

Separate thread - progress list (I)

There is a simple API to start long operations from the user interface processing on the server side.

The server side application has to define two Runnables:

(1.) The first runnable is the one that is the long operation itself. This has nothing to do with UI processing - it is started in a thread that is NO user interface related thread. It's running outside the JSF-scope! - this means you do not have access to FacesContext etc.

(2.) The second runnable it one that is executed after the first runnable is finished. The second runnable is running in the normal user interface related thread, i.e. here you have full access to the JSF environment.

During the long operation a modal popup is shown, so that the user cannot interrupt. The long lasting operation can write messages into an IObserver object - messages are transferred to the client using long polling mechanisms (i.e. there is NO usage of timers, but the messages are sent to the client using long polling).

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_1" objectbinding="#{d.DemoLongOperation}" >
<t:row id="g_2" >
<t:label id="g_3" text="Long operation" width="100" />
<t:button id="g_4" actionListener="#{d.DemoLongOperation.onStartOperation}" text="Start!" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.DefaultScreens;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.ObserverPopup;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.Statusbar;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.polling.LongOperationWithObserverPopup;
import org.eclnt.util.log.IObserver;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoLongOperation}")

public class DemoLongOperation
    extends PageBean
    implements Serializable
{
    public DemoLongOperation(IWorkpageDispatcher dispatcher)
    {
        super(dispatcher);
    }

    public void onStartOperation(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        final IObserver observer = LongOperationWithObserverPopup.prepare("My long Demo Operation");
        // this operation has nothing to do with UI, but can add messages
        // to the observer. Within the operation you should not
        // use UI operations because this is not the UI thread!
        Runnable longOperation = new Runnable()
        {
            public void run()
            {
                for (int i=0; i<10; i++)
                {
                    observer.addMessage("Running... ("+i+")");
                    try 
                    {
                        Thread.currentThread().sleep(3000);
                    }
                    catch (Throwable t) {}
                }
            }
        };
        // this operation is called after the longOperation was finished:
        // here you are within a real request/response processing, i.e.
        // you have full access to all UI operations.
        Runnable finishOperation = new Runnable()
        {
            public void run()
            {
                Statusbar.outputSuccess("Finished!");
            }
        };
        LongOperationWithObserverPopup.run(longOperation,finishOperation);
    }

}

Separate thread - progress list (II)

The page bean component CCCAsynchronousJobProtocol provides nice features to output information from some long lasting operation that is operating in a parallel thread.

During the processing of the long lasing operation the user interface is blocked by a modal popup, so that the user cannot interrupt.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" beanbinding="#{d.DemoPBCCCAsynchronousJobProtocol}" />
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_2" objectbinding="#{d.DemoPBCCCAsynchronousJobProtocol}" >
<t:row id="g_3" >
<t:button id="g_4" actionListener="#{d.DemoPBCCCAsynchronousJobProtocol.onStartAction}" text="Start long operation" width="200+" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import org.eclnt.ccaddons.pbc.CCAsynchronousJobProtocol;
import org.eclnt.ccaddons.pbc.CCAsynchronousJobProtocol.OpenPopupResult;
import org.eclnt.ccaddons.pbc.CCAsynchronousJobProtocol.ProtocolItem;
import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.Statusbar;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoPBCCCAsynchronousJobProtocol}")

public class DemoPBCCCAsynchronousJobProtocol
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoPBCCCAsynchronousJobProtocol(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
    }

    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/demopbcccasynchronousjobprotocol.jsp"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoPBCCCAsynchronousJobProtocol}"; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public void onStartAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        // open the modal popup
        final OpenPopupResult opr = CCAsynchronousJobProtocol.openAsBlockingPopup("Test long running operation",this);
        final CCAsynchronousJobProtocol jb = opr.getProtocolBean();
        // define the long running operation which is executed in a parallel thread
        Runnable lr = new Runnable()
        {
            @Override
            public void run()
            {
                for (int i=0; i<100; i++)
                {
                    try { Thread.sleep(100); } catch (Throwable t) {}
                    jb.setProgressValue(i+1);
                    if (i%5 != 2)
                        jb.addProtocolItemFromAsynchronousProcessing(new ProtocolItem("TEST","Test text " + i,"#C0FFC0","#000000"));
                    else
                        jb.addProtocolItemFromAsynchronousProcessing(new ProtocolItem("TEST","Test text " + i,"#800000","#FFFFFF"));
                }
            }
        };
        // define the operation that is executed in the UI thread after the long operation
        // has ended
        Runnable fr = new Runnable()
        {
            @Override
            public void run()
            {
                Statusbar.outputAlert("Finished!");
            }
        };
        // start
        CCAsynchronousJobProtocol.processLongOperation(jb,lr,fr);
    }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // private usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
}

Asynchronous Processing

Timer

The TIMER component allows to regularly trigger a server side action from client side. You can define the duration in milliseconds that is used as delay between timer calls.

Well, we think we do not have to mention that you can mis-use a timer by setting the duration to a very low value. Any duration that is defined lower than 10 seconds should be treated as critical.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:timer id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoTimer.onTimer}" duration="#{d.DemoTimer.timerDuration}" durationtype="#{d.DemoTimer.durationType}" statusbarneutral="true" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" objectbinding="#{d.DemoTimer}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:label id="g_5" text="Timer Type" width="100" />
<t:label id="g_6" text="#{d.DemoTimer.durationType}" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_7" />
<t:row id="g_8" >
<t:coldistance id="g_9" width="100" />
<t:radiobutton id="g_10" flush="true" group="DT" refvalue="regular" text="Regular" value="#{d.DemoTimer.durationType}" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_11" >
<t:coldistance id="g_12" width="100" />
<t:radiobutton id="g_13" flush="true" group="DT" refvalue="lastroundtrip" text="Last Roundtrip" value="#{d.DemoTimer.durationType}" />
<t:coldistance id="g_14" width="30" />
<t:button id="g_15" actionListener="#{d.DemoTimer.onCauseRoundtrip}" doubleclickenabled="true" text="Cause Roundtrip" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_16" >
<t:coldistance id="g_17" width="100" />
<t:radiobutton id="g_18" flush="true" group="DT" refvalue="lastactivity" text="Last UserActivity" value="#{d.DemoTimer.durationType}" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_19" height="10" />
<t:row id="g_20" >
<t:label id="g_21" text="Timer Duration" width="100" />
<t:field id="g_22" enabled="false" text="#{d.DemoTimer.timerDuration}" width="100" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_23" />
<t:row id="g_24" >
<t:coldistance id="g_25" width="100" />
<t:button id="g_26" actionListener="#{d.DemoTimer.onTimerDuration0}" text="Set to 0" />
<t:button id="g_27" actionListener="#{d.DemoTimer.onTimerDuration3000}" text="Set to 3000" />
<t:coldistance id="g_28" />
<t:button id="g_29" actionListener="#{d.DemoTimer.onTimerDuration10000}" text="Set to 10000" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_30" height="20" />
<t:row id="g_31" >
<t:label id="g_32" text="First Name" width="100" />
<t:field id="g_33" text="#{d.DemoTimer.firstName}" width="150" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_34" >
<t:label id="g_35" text="Last Name" width="100" />
<t:field id="g_36" text="#{d.DemoTimer.lastName}" width="150" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_37" height="20" />
<t:row id="g_38" >
<t:textarea id="g_39" enabled="false" height="100%" text="#{d.DemoTimer.protocol}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_40" >
<t:label id="g_41" text="Time since last activation" />
<t:coldistance id="g_42" width="100%" />
<t:clock id="g_43" clockformat="timeMedium" resettrigger="#{d.DemoTimer.resetTrigger}" startatzero="true" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;
import java.util.Date;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.Statusbar;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.managedbean.IDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoTimer}")

public class DemoTimer
    extends PageBean
    implements Serializable
{
    protected Trigger m_resetTrigger = new Trigger();
    protected String m_durationType = "regular";
    String m_protocol;
    String m_firstName = "";
    String m_lastName = "";
    int m_timerDuration = 3000;
    
    public DemoTimer(IDispatcher dispatcher)
    {
        super(dispatcher);
        onTimer(null);
    }

    public Trigger getResetTrigger() { return m_resetTrigger; }
    public void setResetTrigger(Trigger value) { m_resetTrigger = value; }

    public String getDurationType() { return m_durationType; }
    public void setDurationType(String value) { m_durationType = value; }

    public void setFirstName(String value) { m_firstName = value; }
    public String getFirstName() { return m_firstName; }
    
    public void setLastName(String value) { m_lastName = value; }
    public String getLastName() { return m_lastName; }
    
    public String getProtocol() { return m_protocol; }

    public int getTimerDuration() { return m_timerDuration; }

    public void onTimer(ActionEvent event)
    {
        m_protocol = "Current time: " + (new Date()).getTime() + "\r\n" +
                     "First name: " + m_firstName + "\r\n" +
                     "Last name: " + m_lastName;
        m_resetTrigger.trigger();
    }
    
    public void onTimerDuration0(ActionEvent event)
    {
        m_timerDuration = 0;
    }
    
    public void onTimerDuration3000(ActionEvent event)
    {
        m_timerDuration = 3000;
    }
    
    public void onTimerDuration10000(ActionEvent event)
    {
        m_timerDuration = 10000;
    }
    
    public void onCauseRoundtrip(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        Statusbar.outputMessage("Roundtrip was caused: " + System.currentTimeMillis());
    }

}

Call Server on User Inactivity

Key in some data into the fields. After two seconds of inactity on your side the validation of the form will be called automatically.


The component CALLSERVERONUSERINACTIVITY observes the activity of the user at client side. If the user does not execute any significant event (mouse click, keyboard click) AND if there is no roundtrip for a certain duration, then a call is executed to the server side, invoking the associated action listener.

Examples for using the component:

1. in a form you want to validate the data that the user specifies. Instead of adding some flush to each component you define that after a certain period of time the validation of the data is executed.
2. you want to start a certain activity if the client is not used for a certain while (e.g. shut down some server side functions)

The calling after inactivity is only executed once! So there is no constant calling of the server in case of user inactivity. For constant calling use component TIMER.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:callserveroninactivity id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoFormValidation.onValidate}" duration="2000" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" objectbinding="#{d.DemoFormValidation}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:label id="g_5" text="First Name" width="100" />
<t:field id="g_6" bgpaint="mandatory()" text="#{d.DemoFormValidation.firstName}" width="150" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_7" >
<t:label id="g_8" text="Last Name" width="100" />
<t:field id="g_9" bgpaint="mandatory()" text="#{d.DemoFormValidation.lastName}" width="150" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_10" >
<t:label id="g_11" text="Zip Code / Town" width="100" />
<t:field id="g_12" actionListener="#{d.DemoFormValidation.onZipCodeAction}" flush="true" regex="[0123456789]{5}" regexhint="A German zip code has exactly 5 digits." text="#{d.DemoFormValidation.zipCode}" width="80" />
<t:coldistance id="g_13" />
<t:field id="g_14" text="#{d.DemoFormValidation.town}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_15" height="50" />
<t:row id="g_16" >
<t:coldistance id="g_17" width="100" />
<t:button id="g_18" actionListener="#{d.DemoFormValidation.onValidate}" text="Validate" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;
import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.Statusbar;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.events.BaseActionEventFlush;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.pagebean.PageBean;
import org.eclnt.util.valuemgmt.ValueManager;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoFormValidation}")

public class DemoFormValidation
    extends PageBean
    implements Serializable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    String m_firstName;
    String m_lastName;
    String m_zipCode;
    String m_town;
    
    int m_numberOfErrors = 0;
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    public DemoFormValidation(IWorkpageDispatcher dispatcher)
    {
        super(dispatcher);
    }

    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/demoformvalidation.jsp"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoFormValidation}"; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public String getTown() { return m_town; }
    public void setTown(String value) { this.m_town = value; }

    public String getZipCode() { return m_zipCode; }
    public void setZipCode(String value) { this.m_zipCode = value; }

    public String getLastName() { return m_lastName; }
    public void setLastName(String value) { this.m_lastName = value; }

    public String getFirstName() { return m_firstName; }
    public void setFirstName(String value) { this.m_firstName = value; }

    public void onValidate(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        validate();
    }

    public void onZipCodeAction(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (event instanceof BaseActionEventFlush)
        {
            if ("69245".equals(m_zipCode))
            {
                m_town = "Bammental";
            }
        }
    }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // private usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    private void validate()
    {
        m_numberOfErrors = 0;
        checkNotNull(m_firstName,"First Name");
        checkNotNull(m_lastName,"Last Name");
        if (m_zipCode != null && m_zipCode.trim().length() > 0)
        {
            if (ValueManager.checkIfStringMatchesRegularExpression(m_zipCode,"[0123456789]5") == false)
            {
                m_numberOfErrors++;
            }
            checkNotNull(m_town,"Town");
        }
        if (m_town != null && m_town.trim().length() > 0)
        {
            checkNotNull(m_zipCode,"Zip Code");
        }
    }
    
    private void checkNotNull(String value, String fieldName)
    {
        if (value == null || value.trim().length() == 0)
        {
            Statusbar.outputError("Missing definition: " + fieldName);
            m_numberOfErrors++;
        }
    }
}

Call Server on Trigger

There are situations in which you want to asynchronously start some processing on client side. This is the purpose of the component CALLSERVERONTRIGGER - if triggered by the server, then a call is executed by the client as consequence, invoking the action listener that is defined with the component.

If no duration is defined then the asynchronous calling is executed on client side as fast possible. If a duration is defined, then the client waits correspondingly before calling the server.

Example: you want to show the user a certain screen for a certain duration - and then automatically guide him to the next screen.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:callserverontrigger id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoCallServerByTrigger.onCallServerAction}" duration="1000" trigger="#{d.DemoCallServerByTrigger.trigger}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" objectbinding="#{d.DemoCallServerByTrigger}" >
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:button id="g_5" actionListener="#{d.DemoCallServerByTrigger.onTriggerAction}" text="Trigger!" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.Statusbar;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;
import org.eclnt.workplace.WorkpageDispatchedPageBean;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoCallServerByTrigger}")

public class DemoCallServerByTrigger
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    Trigger m_trigger = new Trigger();
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoCallServerByTrigger(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
    }

    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/democallserverbytrigger.jsp"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoCallServerByTrigger}"; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public Trigger getTrigger() { return m_trigger; }
    public void setTrigger(Trigger value) { this.m_trigger = value; }

    public void onTriggerAction(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_trigger.trigger();
    }

    public void onCallServerAction(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        Statusbar.outputSuccessWithPopup("Server was called!");
    }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // private usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
}

Long Polling

This demo shows how to actively send events from the server to the client side processing. With a certain periodicity there is an event on server side, that causes the client to pick new data by executing a roundtrip.

The central element is the LONGPOLLING component, which is connected to a URL on the one hand and to an actionListener on the other hand. The URL is provided by a obect of type DefaultLongPolling, which you need to register and deregister. The request that is processed by the URL is waiting for a wake up signal on the server side. In the wake up you can pass the information if to continue with request processing or not.

Whenever the request from the LONGPOLLINGURL is passing back a result, the corresponding actionListener is invoked - which is then responsible for the "real roundtrip". - Imagine the LONGPOLLING component to be a virtual button that is pressed not by the user, but by a response coming from an http communication to the server.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:longpolling id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoLongPolling.onLongPollingAction}" comment="#{d.DemoLongPolling.longPollingRendered}" longpollingurl="#{d.DemoLongPolling.longPollingURL}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" objectbinding="#{d.DemoLongPolling}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:button id="g_5" actionListener="#{d.DemoLongPolling.onStartPorcessing}" text="Start long losting Operation" />
<t:coldistance id="g_6" width="100%" />
<t:button id="g_7" actionListener="#{d.DemoLongPolling.onClear}" text="Clear" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_8" >
<t:textarea id="g_9" enabled="false" height="100%" text="#{d.DemoLongPolling.message}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_10" >
<t:label id="g_11" text="Long Polling rendered: " />
<t:label id="g_12" text="#{d.DemoLongPolling.longPollingRendered}" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.Statusbar;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.polling.DefaultLongPolling;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.polling.LongPollingMgr;
import org.eclnt.util.log.CLog;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageLifecycleListener;
import org.eclnt.workplace.WorkpageDefaultLifecycleListener;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoLongPolling}")

public class DemoLongPolling
    extends PageBean
    implements Serializable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // inner classes
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    /**
     * This is the server side processing thread (as simulation...).
     * From time to time it calls the long polling wakup function in order
     * to trigger a long polling "event". (Event meaning, that a response
     * is passed back the client, which then triggeres a calling of
     * the LONGPOLLING's actionListener.
     */
    class ProcessingThread extends Thread
    {
        int i_counter = 0;
        @Override
        public void run()
        {
            while (i_counter <= 20)
            {
                try
                {
                    Thread.currentThread().sleep(1000); // simulation of "heavy processing"
                    // trigger long polling response
                    m_longPolling.wakeup(true);
                    i_counter++;
                }
                catch (Throwable t)
                {
                    CLog.L.log(CLog.LL_ERR,"Error occurred when waking up thread",t);
                    break;
                }
            }
            // end with polling
            m_processingThread = null;
            m_longPolling.wakeup(true);
        }
    }
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    DefaultLongPolling m_longPolling = new DefaultLongPolling();
    ProcessingThread m_processingThread;
    String m_message = new String();
    int m_counter = 0;
    boolean m_longPollingRendered = false;
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    public DemoLongPolling(IWorkpageDispatcher dispatcher)
    {
        super(dispatcher);
        LongPollingMgr.add(m_longPolling);
        getWorkpage().addLifecycleListener(new WorkpageDefaultLifecycleListener() 
        {
            public void reactOnDestroyed()
            {
                LongPollingMgr.remove(m_longPolling); // clean up long polling
            }
        });
    }
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public String getLongPollingURL() 
    { 
        return m_longPolling.getURL(); 
    }
    public boolean getLongPollingRendered() { return m_longPollingRendered; }

    public void onClear(ActionEvent event)
    {
        m_message = "";
    }
    
    /**
     * This method is called by the start button.
     */
    public void onStartPorcessing(ActionEvent event)
    {
        if (m_processingThread != null)
        {
            Statusbar.outputError("Server side process already started - please wait until current processing has finished.");
            return;
        }
        m_longPollingRendered = true;
        m_processingThread = new ProcessingThread();
        m_processingThread.start();
    }
    
    /**
     * This method is called by the LONGPOLLING component on client side, when
     * it receives a response.
     */
    public void onLongPollingAction(ActionEvent event)
    {
        if (m_processingThread != null)
        {
            int counter = m_processingThread.i_counter; 
            m_message = "Current counter in porocessing thread: " + m_processingThread.i_counter + "\n" + m_message;
        }
        else
        {
            m_message = "No processing thread available anymore.\n" +
                        "Stopping long polling.";
            m_longPollingRendered = false;
        }
    }   
    
    public String getMessage() { return m_message; }
    
}

Long Polling with WebSocket Connection

Using a WEBSOCKETPOLLING component is the easiest and most efficient way to set up some processing, in which events from the server side are published to the client.

Imaging the WEBSOCKETPOLLING component to be an invisible button, which always activates its actionListener once a server side event occurs. The connection between the "button" and the server side event is a WebSocket connection.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:websocketpolling id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling.onWebSocketAction}" duration="100" websocketurl="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling.webSocketUrl}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" objectbinding="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling}">
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:label id="g_5" text="URL" width="100" />
<t:label id="g_6" cutwidth="true" text="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling.webSocketUrl}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_7" >
<t:coldistance id="g_8" width="100" />
<t:button id="g_9" actionListener="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling.onStopAction}" text="Stop thread processing" />
<t:coldistance id="g_10" width="5" />
<t:button id="g_11" actionListener="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling.onRestartAction}" text="Restart thread processing" width="100+" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_12" >
<t:textarea id="g_13" height="100%" text="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling.protocol}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.polling.LongPollingMgr;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.polling.websocket.DefaultLongPollingWebSocket;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;
import org.eclnt.workplace.WorkpageDefaultLifecycleListener;
import org.eclnt.workplace.WorkpageDispatchedPageBean;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling}")

public class DemoWebSocketPolling
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // inner classes
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    /**
     * This is some server side "event producing thread". 
     */
    public class MyThread extends Thread
    {
        boolean i_threadStop = false;
        @Override
        public void run()
        {
            for (int i=0; i<100; i++)
            {
                try { Thread.sleep(500); } catch (Throwable t) {}
                if (i_threadStop == true) break;
                m_counter++;
                // waking up == sending an event to the client side
                m_longPollingWebSocket.wakeup(true);
            }
            if (m_thread == this) m_thread = null;
        }
    }
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    /**
     * Server side part of the web socket management.
     */
    DefaultLongPollingWebSocket m_longPollingWebSocket;
    
    MyThread m_thread;
    int m_counter = 0;
    String m_protocol = "Protocol:\n";

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoWebSocketPolling(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
        // first creat the web socket part - then register!
        m_longPollingWebSocket = new DefaultLongPollingWebSocket();
        LongPollingMgr.add(m_longPollingWebSocket);
        // if registering something you have to de-register. In this example: de-registration
        // is done when closing the workpage in the workplace. BUT: there may be other, better
        // points of de-registration in your scenario.
        getWorkpage().addLifecycleListener(new WorkpageDefaultLifecycleListener()
        {
            @Override
            public void reactOnDestroyed()
            {
                if (m_thread != null)
                    m_thread.i_threadStop = true;
                LongPollingMgr.remove(m_longPollingWebSocket);
            }
        });
        m_thread = new MyThread();
        m_thread.start();
    }

    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/demowebsocketpolling.jsp"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoWebSocketPolling}"; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    /**
     * The URL for the web socket is passed back by the {@link DefaultLongPollingWebSocket} instance.
     */
    public String getWebSocketUrl() { return m_longPollingWebSocket.getURL(); }
    
    public String getProtocol() { return m_protocol; }
    public void setProtocol(String value) { this.m_protocol = value; }

    /**
     * This is the actionListener of the WEBSOCKETPOLLING component. The function
     * is called every time an event is communicated to the client side via web socket.
     */
    public void onWebSocketAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_protocol += "\nCurrent counter: " + m_counter; 
    }

    public void onStopAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (m_thread != null)
            m_thread.i_threadStop = true;
        m_thread = null;
    }

    public void onRestartAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (m_thread != null)
            return;
        m_thread = new MyThread();
        m_thread.start();
    }
}

Unified Polling

The components LONGPOLLINGWEBSOCKET (polling via WebSockets) and LONGPOLLING (polling via URL) are very similar - both from component configuration point of view and from Java-programming point of view.

In many cases the selection of the proper component is dependent on the customer's network. There are still situations in which a WebSocket communication is not supported yet...

The page bean component TPBC:UNIFIEDPOLLING contains both the WebSocket- and the URL-based polling - and you can easily switch the mode by central configuration - by calling "CCUnifiedPolling.initializePollingType(..)".

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" beanbinding="#{d.DemoPBCUnifiedPolling}" >
<t:unifiedpolling id="g_6" actionListener="#{d.DemoPBCUnifiedPolling.onPollingAction}" duration="100" pagebeanbinding="#{d.DemoPBCUnifiedPolling.polling}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_4" objectbinding="#{d.DemoPBCUnifiedPolling}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue[&#39;@defaultrowdistance@&#39;]}" >
<t:row id="g_5" coldistance="#{ccstylevalue[&#39;@defaultcoldistance@&#39;]}" >
<t:label id="g_14" text="Server-side event generation:" />
<t:button id="g_10" actionListener="#{d.DemoPBCUnifiedPolling.onStartAction}" text="Start" width="100+" />
<t:button id="g_12" actionListener="#{d.DemoPBCUnifiedPolling.onStopAction}" text="Stop" width="100+" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_3" >
<t:textarea id="g_8" height="100%" stylevariant="cc_code" text="#{d.DemoPBCUnifiedPolling.protocol}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.polling.ENUMPollingType;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.polling.UNIFIEDPOLLINGBinding;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoPBCUnifiedPolling}")

public class DemoPBCUnifiedPolling
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // inner classes
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public class MyThread extends Thread
    {
        boolean m_stopped = false;
        @Override
        public void run()
        {
            while (m_stopped == false)
            {
                try { sleep(2000); } catch (Throwable t) {}
                if (m_stopped == false)
                    m_polling.wakeup(true);
            }
        }
    }
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    String m_protocol = "";
    UNIFIEDPOLLINGBinding m_polling = new UNIFIEDPOLLINGBinding();
    MyThread m_thread;

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoPBCUnifiedPolling(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);
        // central configuration: should be called e.g. during startup!
        UNIFIEDPOLLINGBinding.initializePollingType(ENUMPollingType.WEBSOCKET);
        // you can also directly set the polling type by using component
        // attribute TPBC:UNIFIEDPOLLING-POLLINTYPE - in this case the
        // component definition overrules the general definition
    }

    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/demopbcunifiedpolling.xml"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoPBCUnifiedPolling}"; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public String getProtocol() { return m_protocol; }
    public void setProtocol(String value) { this.m_protocol = value; }
    
    public UNIFIEDPOLLINGBinding getPolling() { return m_polling; }
    
    public void onStartAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_protocol += "START called\n";
        if (m_thread != null)
        {
            m_thread.m_stopped = true;
            m_thread = null;
        }
        m_thread = new MyThread();
        m_thread.start();
    }

    public void onStopAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_protocol += "STOP called\n";
        if (m_thread != null)
        {
            m_thread.m_stopped = true;
            m_thread = null;
        }
    }
    
    public void onPollingAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_protocol += "Server side event: " + System.currentTimeMillis() + "\n";
    }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // private usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
}

Dialog Message Bus

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" beanbinding="#{d.DemoDialogMessageBusAsynchronous}" />
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_4" objectbinding="#{d.DemoDialogMessageBusAsynchronous}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue[&#39;@defaultrowdistance@&#39;]}" >
<t:row id="g_6" coldistance="#{ccstylevalue[&#39;@defaultcoldistance@&#39;]}" >
<t:button id="g_5" actionListener="#{d.DemoDialogMessageBusAsynchronous.onDirectSendAction}" text="Directly send" />
<t:button id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoDialogMessageBusAsynchronous.onStartAction}" text="Start" width="100" />
<t:button id="g_8" actionListener="#{d.DemoDialogMessageBusAsynchronous.onStopAction}" text="Stop" width="100" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_3" >
<t:textarea id="g_10" height="100%" stylevariant="cc_code" text="#{d.DemoDialogMessageBusAsynchronous.protocol}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.messages.DefaultDialogMessageBusListener;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.messages.DialogMessageBus;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.messages.IDialogMessageBusListener;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.pagebean.IDestroyable;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoDialogMessageBusAsynchronous}")

public class DemoDialogMessageBusAsynchronous
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable, IDestroyable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // inner classes
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    class MyMessage
    {
        String i_text;
        public MyMessage(String text)
        {
            i_text = text;
        }
        public String getText() { return i_text; } 
    }
    
    class MyThread extends Thread
    {
        int i_counter = 0;
        boolean i_stopped = false;
        DialogMessageBus i_bus;
        public MyThread(DialogMessageBus bus)
        {
            i_bus = bus;
        }

        @Override
        public void run()
        {
            while (i_stopped == false)
            {
                try { Thread.sleep(2000); } catch (Throwable t) {}
                i_counter++;
                i_bus.publishMessage(new MyMessage("Current counter: " + i_counter));
            }
        }
    }
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    String m_protocol = "Protocol:\n";
    MyThread m_thread;
    IDialogMessageBusListener m_messageBusListener;

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoDialogMessageBusAsynchronous(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
        m_messageBusListener = new DefaultDialogMessageBusListener()
        {
            @Override
            /*
             * This method is always executed in the "UI processing thread".
             */
            public void reactOnMessage(Object o)
            {
                if (o instanceof MyMessage)
                {
                    MyMessage mm = (MyMessage)o;
                    m_protocol += mm.getText()+"\n";
                }
            }
        };
        DialogMessageBus.instance().addListener(m_messageBusListener);
    }

    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/demodialogmessagebusasynchronous.xml"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoDialogMessageBusAsynchronous}"; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public String getProtocol() { return m_protocol; }
    public void setProtocol(String value) { this.m_protocol = value; }

    /**
     * This message is sent directly from the "UI processing thread".
     */
    public void onDirectSendAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        DialogMessageBus.instance().publishMessage(new MyMessage("This is a directly sent message. " + System.currentTimeMillis()));
    }

    public void onStartAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (m_thread == null)
        {
            m_thread = new MyThread(DialogMessageBus.instance());
            m_thread.start();
        }
    }
    
    public void onStopAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (m_thread != null)
        {
            m_thread.i_stopped = true;
            m_thread = null;
        }
    }

    @Override
    public void destroy()
    {
        DialogMessageBus.instance().removeListener(m_messageBusListener);
        if (m_thread != null)
        {
            m_thread.i_stopped = true;
            m_thread = null;
        }   
    }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // private usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
}

Long Operations - Simple Variant

There is a simple API to start long operations from the user interface processing on the server side.

The server side application has to define two Runnables:

(1.) The first runnable is the one that is the long operation itself. This has nothing to do with UI processing - it is started in a thread that is NO user interface related thread. It's running outside the JSF-scope! - this means you do not have access to FacesContext etc.

(2.) The second runnable it one that is executed after the first runnable is finished. The second runnable is running in the normal user interface related thread, i.e. here you have full access to the JSF environment.

During the long operation a modal popup is shown, so that the user cannot interrupt. The long lasting operation can write messages into an IObserver object - messages are transferred to the client using long polling mechanisms (i.e. there is NO usage of timers, but the messages are sent to the client using long polling).

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_1" objectbinding="#{d.DemoLongOperation}" >
<t:row id="g_2" >
<t:label id="g_3" text="Long operation" width="100" />
<t:button id="g_4" actionListener="#{d.DemoLongOperation.onStartOperation}" text="Start!" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.DefaultScreens;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.ObserverPopup;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.Statusbar;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.polling.LongOperationWithObserverPopup;
import org.eclnt.util.log.IObserver;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoLongOperation}")

public class DemoLongOperation
    extends PageBean
    implements Serializable
{
    public DemoLongOperation(IWorkpageDispatcher dispatcher)
    {
        super(dispatcher);
    }

    public void onStartOperation(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        final IObserver observer = LongOperationWithObserverPopup.prepare("My long Demo Operation");
        // this operation has nothing to do with UI, but can add messages
        // to the observer. Within the operation you should not
        // use UI operations because this is not the UI thread!
        Runnable longOperation = new Runnable()
        {
            public void run()
            {
                for (int i=0; i<10; i++)
                {
                    observer.addMessage("Running... ("+i+")");
                    try 
                    {
                        Thread.currentThread().sleep(3000);
                    }
                    catch (Throwable t) {}
                }
            }
        };
        // this operation is called after the longOperation was finished:
        // here you are within a real request/response processing, i.e.
        // you have full access to all UI operations.
        Runnable finishOperation = new Runnable()
        {
            public void run()
            {
                Statusbar.outputSuccess("Finished!");
            }
        };
        LongOperationWithObserverPopup.run(longOperation,finishOperation);
    }

}

Long Operations - Nicer Variant

The page bean component CCCAsynchronousJobProtocol provides nice features to output information from some long lasting operation that is operating in a parallel thread.

During the processing of the long lasing operation the user interface is blocked by a modal popup, so that the user cannot interrupt.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" beanbinding="#{d.DemoPBCCCAsynchronousJobProtocol}" />
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_2" objectbinding="#{d.DemoPBCCCAsynchronousJobProtocol}" >
<t:row id="g_3" >
<t:button id="g_4" actionListener="#{d.DemoPBCCCAsynchronousJobProtocol.onStartAction}" text="Start long operation" width="200+" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import org.eclnt.ccaddons.pbc.CCAsynchronousJobProtocol;
import org.eclnt.ccaddons.pbc.CCAsynchronousJobProtocol.OpenPopupResult;
import org.eclnt.ccaddons.pbc.CCAsynchronousJobProtocol.ProtocolItem;
import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.Statusbar;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoPBCCCAsynchronousJobProtocol}")

public class DemoPBCCCAsynchronousJobProtocol
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoPBCCCAsynchronousJobProtocol(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
    }

    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/demopbcccasynchronousjobprotocol.jsp"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoPBCCCAsynchronousJobProtocol}"; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public void onStartAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        // open the modal popup
        final OpenPopupResult opr = CCAsynchronousJobProtocol.openAsBlockingPopup("Test long running operation",this);
        final CCAsynchronousJobProtocol jb = opr.getProtocolBean();
        // define the long running operation which is executed in a parallel thread
        Runnable lr = new Runnable()
        {
            @Override
            public void run()
            {
                for (int i=0; i<100; i++)
                {
                    try { Thread.sleep(100); } catch (Throwable t) {}
                    jb.setProgressValue(i+1);
                    if (i%5 != 2)
                        jb.addProtocolItemFromAsynchronousProcessing(new ProtocolItem("TEST","Test text " + i,"#C0FFC0","#000000"));
                    else
                        jb.addProtocolItemFromAsynchronousProcessing(new ProtocolItem("TEST","Test text " + i,"#800000","#FFFFFF"));
                }
            }
        };
        // define the operation that is executed in the UI thread after the long operation
        // has ended
        Runnable fr = new Runnable()
        {
            @Override
            public void run()
            {
                Statusbar.outputAlert("Finished!");
            }
        };
        // start
        CCAsynchronousJobProtocol.processLongOperation(jb,lr,fr);
    }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // private usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
}

One Long Polling for different Events

Instead of having many LONGPOLLING components that work in parallel (each one reserving one connection!) it makes sense to have some central LONGPOLLING component and do all the asynchronous eventing via this component.

In the example there are two different events (simulated by two threads firing server side events), that use one LONGPOLLING. The events are queued into one event queue (m_events), when passing an event then the LONGPOLLING is triggered in order to invoke the client.

Please carefully note the usage of "synchronized" within the processing the events in the vector "m_events"!

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_3" >
<t:longpolling id="g_4" actionListener="#{d.DemoLongPollingCentral.onLongPollingAction}" longpollingurl="#{d.DemoLongPollingCentral.longPollingURL}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_10" objectbinding="#{d.DemoLongPollingCentral}" >
<t:row id="g_1" >
<t:textarea id="g_7" height="100%" text="#{d.DemoLongPollingCentral.protocol}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:rowstatusbar id="g_12" />
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;
import java.util.Vector;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.pagebean.PageBean;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.polling.DefaultLongPolling;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.polling.LongPollingMgr;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;
import org.eclnt.workplace.WorkpageDefaultLifecycleListener;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoLongPollingCentral}")

public class DemoLongPollingCentral
    extends PageBean
    implements Serializable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // inner classes
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    public class MyEvent
    {
        Object i_source;
        String i_text;
        public MyEvent(Object source, String text)
        {
            i_source = source;
            i_text = text;
        }
    }
    
    public class Event1Creator extends Thread
    {
        int i_counter = 0;
        @Override
        public void run()
        {
            while (m_active)
            {
                try { Thread.currentThread().sleep(1000); } catch (Throwable t) {}
                i_counter++;
                throwEvent(this,"Event1 - " + i_counter);
            }
        }
    }
    
    public class Event2Creator extends Thread
    {
        int i_counter = 0;
        @Override
        public void run()
        {
            while (m_active)
            {
                try { Thread.currentThread().sleep(3333); } catch (Throwable t) {}
                i_counter++;
                throwEvent(this,"Event2 - " + i_counter);
            }
        }
    }
    
    public class MyLongPolling extends DefaultLongPolling
    {
    }
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    Event1Creator m_event1Creator;
    Event2Creator m_event2Creator;
    
    Object m_syncher = new Object();
    
    boolean m_active = true;
    MyLongPolling m_longPolling;
    
    String m_protocol = "";
    
    Vector<MyEvent> m_events = new Vector<MyEvent>();
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoLongPollingCentral(IWorkpageDispatcher dispatcher)
    {
        super(dispatcher);
        m_longPolling = new MyLongPolling();
        m_event1Creator = new Event1Creator();
        m_event2Creator = new Event2Creator();
        m_event1Creator.start();
        m_event2Creator.start();
        LongPollingMgr.add(m_longPolling);
        getWorkpage().addLifecycleListener(new WorkpageDefaultLifecycleListener()
        {
            @Override
            public void reactOnDestroyed()
            {
                super.reactOnDestroyed();
                m_active = false;
                LongPollingMgr.remove(m_longPolling);
                m_longPolling = null;
            }
        });
    }

    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/demolongpollingcentral.jsp"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoLongPollingCentral}"; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public String getLongPollingURL() { return m_longPolling.getURL(); }
    public String getProtocol() { return m_protocol; }

    public void onLongPollingAction(ActionEvent actionEvent)
    {
        MyEvent[] events;
        synchronized (m_syncher) 
        {
            events = new MyEvent[m_events.size()];
            m_events.toArray(events);
            m_events.clear();
        }
        for (MyEvent event: events)
        {
            executeEvent(event);
        }
    }
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // private usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    private void throwEvent(Object source, String text)
    {
        MyEvent event = new MyEvent(source,text);
        synchronized (m_syncher) 
        {
            m_events.add(event);
        }
        if (m_longPolling != null)
            m_longPolling.wakeup(true);
    }
    
    private void executeEvent(MyEvent event)
    {
        String line = "Event: " + event.i_source.getClass().getSimpleName() + ": " + event.i_text + "\n";
        m_protocol += line;
    }
}

Thread Synchronization
