import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.events.BaseActionEventClientSubDevice;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;
import org.eclnt.workplace.WorkpageDispatchedBean;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoClientSubDevice}")

public class DemoClientSubDevice
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    String m_sendValue;
    public String getSendValue() { return m_sendValue; }
    public void setSendValue(String value) { this.m_sendValue = value; }

    Trigger m_sendTrigger = new Trigger();
    public Trigger getSendTrigger() { return m_sendTrigger; }

    String m_protocol = "";
    public String getProtocol() { return m_protocol; }
    public void setProtocol(String value) { this.m_protocol = value; }


    public DemoClientSubDevice(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
    }

    public void onSendAction(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_sendTrigger.trigger();
    }

    public void onSubDeviceAction(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (event instanceof BaseActionEventClientSubDevice)
        {
            m_protocol = ((BaseActionEventClientSubDevice) event).getSubDeviceSendValue() + "\n" + m_protocol;
        }
    }

}

Client HTTP Receiver (Java Client only)

Open up a browser (Firefox, Internet Explorer) and open the URL http://localhost:4444/Hello - you will see an event inside the protocol that is output.

By using the component CLIENTHTTPRECEIVER you are able to send http-get-requests to the client. The client will receive the request and notiy the server processing by calling the assigned actionListener method. The query string of the http-get-request is passed as event parameter.

What is the main purpose? You can integrate other client software in a smart way. Imagine you have a barcode scanner that needs to trigger a certain client processing. The barcode scanner software can send an http request to the client processing and by this automatically trigger some server processing.

Please pay attention: any software can now send http requests to your client - when using the CLIENTHTTPRECEIVER component. You must as consequence establish corresponding security checks on server side to check if the request really can be executed. E.g. you may pass some tokens as URL parameters by which the http-sender must authenticate itself.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:clienthttpreceiver id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoClientHttpReceiver.onClientHttpReceive}" port="4444" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" objectbinding="#{d.DemoClientHttpReceiver}">
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:label id="g_5" text="Protocol" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_6" >
<t:textarea id="g_7" enabled="false" height="100%" text="#{d.DemoClientHttpReceiver.protocol}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.events.BaseActionEventClientHttpReceive;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.managedbean.IDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoClientHttpReceiver}")

public class DemoClientHttpReceiver
    extends PageBean
    implements Serializable
{
    public DemoClientHttpReceiver(IDispatcher dispatcher)
    {
        super(dispatcher);
    }

    protected String m_protocol = "...no http received yet...\r\n\r\n";
    public String getProtocol() { return m_protocol; }
    public void setProtocol(String value) { m_protocol = value; }

    public void onClientHttpReceive(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        BaseActionEventClientHttpReceive baechr = (BaseActionEventClientHttpReceive)event;
        m_protocol += baechr.getQueryString() + ", " + baechr.getHostName() + ", " + baechr.getHostAddress() + "\r\n";
    }

}

Client HTTP Sender

The component CLIENTHTTPSENDER allows to send a URL from the client to any other receiving system. The response of the http-request can be transferred back to the server processing.

A typical usage scenario for this component is: you want to connect to a client side system that is accessed through an http interface. From the server side processing you typically cannot connect to the client side because of firewall restrictions. Now, with using the CLIENTHTTPSENDER component, the connection to your client side system is done from client side - the result is transferred back into the server side processing.

Please do not mis-use this component! You should not / must not use this component as multi-prupose communicator to reach systems which you are not allowed to reach from server side because of network restrictions!

The callback to the server side processing is only done if the attribute URLCALLBACK is set to true. On server side a special event (BaseActionEventClientHttpSend) is passed. The response of the called system is passed back as Hexstring/ byte array or UTF-8 string.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:clienthttpsender id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoClientHttpSend.onSendAction}" httpheaderparams="#{d.DemoClientHttpSend.headerParamsCSV}" trigger="#{d.DemoClientHttpSend.trigger}" url="#{d.DemoClientHttpSend.url}" urlcallback="true" urlpostdata="#{d.DemoClientHttpSend.postString}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" objectbinding="#{d.DemoClientHttpSend}" rowdistance="4" >
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:label id="g_5" text="URL" width="100" />
<t:field id="g_6" text="#{d.DemoClientHttpSend.url}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_7" >
<t:label id="g_8" text="Post String" width="100" />
<t:textarea id="g_9" height="75" text="#{d.DemoClientHttpSend.postString}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_10" >
<t:label id="g_11" text="Http Header CSV" width="100" />
<t:textarea id="g_12" height="50" text="#{d.DemoClientHttpSend.headerParamsCSV}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_13" >
<t:coldistance id="g_14" width="100" />
<t:button id="g_15" actionListener="#{d.DemoClientHttpSend.onTrigger}" text="Execute Request" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_16" height="20" />
<t:row id="g_17" >
<t:label id="g_18" rowalignmenty="top" text="Result" width="100" />
<t:textarea id="g_19" height="100%" text="#{d.DemoClientHttpSend.result}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.events.BaseActionEventClientHttpSend;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoClientHttpSend}")

public class DemoClientHttpSend
    extends PageBean
    implements Serializable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // inner classes
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    protected Trigger m_trigger = new Trigger();
    protected String m_result;
    protected String m_url = "http://www.captaincasa.com/index.html";
    protected String m_postString = null;
    protected String m_headerParamsCSV = null;
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoClientHttpSend(IWorkpageDispatcher dispatcher)
    {
        super(dispatcher);
        m_postString = "<KAHA_NAME>M&#246;ller</KAHA_NAME>";
    }
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // private usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    public Trigger getTrigger() { return m_trigger; }
    public void setTrigger(Trigger value) { m_trigger = value; }

    public String getResult() { return m_result; }
    public void setResult(String value) { m_result = value; }

    public String getUrl() { return m_url; }
    public void setUrl(String value) { m_url = value; }

    public String getHeaderParamsCSV() { return m_headerParamsCSV; }
    public void setHeaderParamsCSV(String headerParamsCSV) { m_headerParamsCSV = headerParamsCSV; }

    public void setPostString(String value) 
    { 
        m_postString = value; 
        if (m_postString != null && m_postString.length() == 0)
            m_postString = null;
    }
    public String getPostString() { return m_postString; }
    
    public void onSendAction(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (event instanceof BaseActionEventClientHttpSend)
        {
            BaseActionEventClientHttpSend sevent = (BaseActionEventClientHttpSend)event;
            m_result = sevent.getSuccess() + "\n\n" + sevent.getResponseAsUTF8String();
            if (sevent.getSuccess() == false)
            {
                m_result += "\n\nPlease check the URL first. If correct: open development mode in browser and check the log."
                        + "\nIn the log you typically find the explanation why the communication failed - typical example: the page has to define its CORS policy to allow the client to communicate to different servers.";
            }
        }
    }

    public void onTrigger(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_trigger.trigger();
    }

}

Client Datagram Receiver (Java Client only)

The component CLIENTDATAGRAMRECEIVER allows to send IP-datagrams (UDP messages) to the user interface. The component receives the message and passes it to the server side processing by calling its action listener.

The component is typically used in the context of sub-system integration: e.g. there are barcode scanners sending the event about having read a barcode via http datagram.

The byte stream that is received through the datagram is part of the event inforation on server side. You can either read it as hexadeicmal string representation or as byte array.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:clientdatagramreceiver id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoClientDatagramReceiver.onReceive}" buffersize="1000" port="54001" timeout="50000" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" objectbinding="#{d.DemoClientDatagramReceiver}">
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:label id="g_5" text="Datagram" width="120" />
<t:field id="g_6" actionListener="#{d.DemoClientDatagramReceiver.onReceive}" text="#{d.DemoClientDatagramReceiver.datagram}" width="150" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.events.BaseActionEventClientDatagramReceive;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoClientDatagramReceiver}")

public class DemoClientDatagramReceiver
    extends PageBean
    implements Serializable
{
    public DemoClientDatagramReceiver(IWorkpageDispatcher dispatcher)
    {
        super(dispatcher);
    }
    
    public void onReceive(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (event instanceof BaseActionEventClientDatagramReceive)
        {
            BaseActionEventClientDatagramReceive baecdr = (BaseActionEventClientDatagramReceive)event;
            m_datagram = baecdr.getDatagramHexString();
        }
    }

    protected String m_datagram;
    public String getDatagram() { return m_datagram; }
    public void setDatagram(String value) { m_datagram = value; }

}

Client Applet Context (Java Client only)

The component APPLETCONTEXTSHOWDOCUMENT is a quite special one: it allows to access the applet context and to open HTML documents within the browser from which the applet was started. You can both pass the HTML page and pass the name of the target frame where to show the document.

It only operates within an applet environment. If not running within an applet environment, the component will not throw any errors but just ignore commands to open up pages.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:appletcontextshowdocument id="g_2" target="#{d.DemoAppletContext.target}" trigger="#{d.DemoAppletContext.trigger}" url="#{d.DemoAppletContext.url}" usedesktop="true" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" objectbinding="#{d.DemoAppletContext}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:label id="g_5" text="URL" width="100" />
<t:field id="g_6" text="#{d.DemoAppletContext.url}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_7" >
<t:label id="g_8" text="Target Frame" width="100" />
<t:field id="g_9" text="#{d.DemoAppletContext.target}" width="100" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_10" >
<t:coldistance id="g_11" width="100" />
<t:button id="g_12" actionListener="#{d.DemoAppletContext.onShowDocument}" text="Show Document" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoAppletContext}")

public class DemoAppletContext
    extends PageBean
    implements Serializable
{
    public DemoAppletContext(IWorkpageDispatcher dispatcher)
    {
        super(dispatcher);
    }

    protected Trigger m_trigger = new Trigger();
    protected String m_url = "http://www.captaincasa.com";
    protected String m_target = "_blank";

    public String getTarget() { return m_target; }
    public void setTarget(String value) { m_target = value; }

    public Trigger getTrigger() { return m_trigger; }
    
    public String getUrl() { return m_url; }
    public void setUrl(String value) { m_url = value; }

    public void onShowDocument(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_trigger.trigger();
    }
}

PDF Renderer

The PDFRENDERER component is able to render a PDF bytestream directly into the user interface. There is no necessity for having some Adobe Reader installed in the frontend - the rendering is done through pure Java.

The PDF format must adhere to documents display-able in Adobe Acrobat Reader 5.0.

...of course: you can also use the BROWSER component and pass a URL ending with ".pdf". But: the PDFRENDERER component gives you a tighter level of intergration. As you see in the server side Java program the PDF is rendered directly into a property string which is references by the component ...that's it.

When using the component as part of your screen definition make sure that the PDFRenderer.jar library is referenced within your applet of webstart definition.

The PDFRENDER component supports clients printing as well. Printing is started by using the TRIGGERPRINT attribute. You can pre-select if the user should see a print dialog and/or you can pre-select the client side printer by defining its name. If on client side no printer definition can be found, then the print dialog is opened automatically.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_1" objectbinding="#{d.DemoPdfRenderer}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_2" >
<t:pdfrenderer id="g_3" bgpaint="rectangle(0,0,100%,100%,#000000A0,#00000040,vertical)" filename="{temp}/mypdf.pdf" height="100%" padding="top:10;bottom:5;left:10;right:10" pdf="#{d.DemoPdfRenderer.pdf}" triggerprint="#{d.DemoPdfRenderer.trigger}" width="100%" withprintdialog="true" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_4" height="20" />
<t:row id="g_5" >
<t:label id="g_6" text="Trigger Printing" width="120" />
<t:button id="g_7" actionListener="#{d.DemoPdfRenderer.onTriggerPrint}" text="Print (triggered by Server)" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_8" >
<t:label id="g_9" text="Client side PDF" width="120" />
<t:fileuploadbutton id="g_10" actionListener="#{d.DemoPdfRenderer.onLoadPdfAction}" fileextensions="pdf" maxfilesize="5000000" text="Load PDF" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_11" >
<t:label id="g_12" text="Clear PDF" width="120" />
<t:button id="g_13" actionListener="#{d.DemoPdfRenderer.onClear}" text="Clear" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.events.BaseActionEventUpload;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.managedbean.IDispatcher;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.util.WebResourceReader;
import org.eclnt.util.file.FileManager;
import org.eclnt.util.valuemgmt.ValueManager;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoPdfRenderer}")

public class DemoPdfRenderer
    extends PageBean
    implements Serializable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // inner classes
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    protected Trigger m_trigger = new Trigger();
    protected String m_pdf;
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    public DemoPdfRenderer(IDispatcher dispatcher)
    {
        super(dispatcher);
        initRefComponent("pdfrenderer");
        byte[] initialPdf = WebResourceReader.readFileIntoByteArray("/pdf/pdftest1.pdf");
        m_pdf = ValueManager.encodeHexString(initialPdf);
    }
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    public Trigger getTrigger() { return m_trigger; }
    public void setTrigger(Trigger value) { m_trigger = value; }

    public String getPdf() { return m_pdf; }
    public void setPdf(String value) { m_pdf = value; }

    public void onLoadPdfAction(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (event instanceof BaseActionEventUpload)
        {
            BaseActionEventUpload baeu = (BaseActionEventUpload)event;
            byte[] bytes = baeu.getHexBytes();
            m_pdf = ValueManager.encodeHexString(bytes);
        }
    }

    public void onTriggerPrint(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_trigger.trigger();
    }
    
    public void onClear(ActionEvent event)
    {
        m_pdf = null;
    }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // private usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

}

Barcode Scan Demo

This demo is an example for implementing a screen that is used with a barcode scanner that is connected by simulating keyboard input.

The focus is always redirected to the article id field so that the scanner input is directed into the right component.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:timer id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoTouchScan.onSetBarcodeFocus}" duration="5000" />
<t:sound id="g_3" sound="/sounds/beep.wav" trigger="#{d.DemoTouchScan.soundTrigger}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_4" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" objectbinding="#{d.DemoTouchScan}">
<t:row id="g_5" >
<t:label id="g_6" text="Article" width="100" />
<t:field id="g_7" actionListener="#{d.DemoTouchScan.onArticleIdAction}" flush="true" flushtimer="200" requestfocus="#{d.DemoTouchScan.articleIdFocus}" text="#{d.DemoTouchScan.articleId}" touchlayout="numeric" touchsupport="true" width="200" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_8" >
<t:label id="g_9" text="Quantity" width="100" />
<t:formattedfield id="g_10" actionListener="#{d.DemoTouchScan.onQuantityAction}" flush="true" format="int" touchsupport="true" value="#{d.DemoTouchScan.quantity}" width="50" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_11" height="20" />
<t:rowline id="g_12" background="#c0c0c0" height="1" />
<t:rowdistance id="g_13" height="20" />
<t:row id="g_14" >
<t:fixgrid id="g_15" background="#F0F0F0" bordercolor="#{ccstylevalue.ccLightBorderColor}" borderheight="1" borderwidth="1" height="100%" objectbinding="#{d.DemoTouchScan.orderRows}" sbvisibleamount="30" width="100%" >
<t:gridcol id="g_16" text="Article Id" width="100" >
<t:label id="g_17" text=".{articleId}" />
</t:gridcol>
<t:gridcol id="g_18" text="Text" width="100%" >
<t:label id="g_19" text=".{articleText}" />
</t:gridcol>
<t:gridcol id="g_20" text="Quantity" width="50" >
<t:formattedfield id="g_21" format="int" touchsupport="true" value=".{quantity}" />
</t:gridcol>
</t:fixgrid>
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.impl.FIXGRIDItem;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.impl.FIXGRIDListBinding;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.session.RequestFocusManager;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoTouchScan}")

public class DemoTouchScan
    extends PageBean
    implements Serializable
{
    public DemoTouchScan(IWorkpageDispatcher dispatcher)
    {
        super(dispatcher);
    }

    protected Trigger m_soundTrigger = new Trigger();
    public Trigger getSoundTrigger() { return m_soundTrigger; }
    public void setSoundTrigger(Trigger value) { m_soundTrigger = value; }

    protected FIXGRIDListBinding<OrderRow> m_orderRows = new FIXGRIDListBinding<OrderRow>();
    public FIXGRIDListBinding<OrderRow> getOrderRows() { return m_orderRows; }
    public void setOrderRows(FIXGRIDListBinding<OrderRow> value) { m_orderRows = value; }

    public class OrderRow extends FIXGRIDItem implements java.io.Serializable
    {
        protected int m_quantity;
        public int getQuantity() { return m_quantity; }
        public void setQuantity(int value) { m_quantity = value; }

        protected String m_articleText;
        public String getArticleText() { return m_articleText; }
        public void setArticleText(String value) { m_articleText = value; }

        protected String m_articleId;
        public String getArticleId() { return m_articleId; }
        public void setArticleId(String value) { m_articleId = value; }

    }

    protected int m_quantity = 1;
    public int getQuantity() { return m_quantity; }
    public void setQuantity(int value) { m_quantity = value; }

    public void onArticleIdAction(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_articleIdFocus = RequestFocusManager.getNewRequestFocusCounter()+"";   
        OrderRow or = new OrderRow();
        or.setArticleId(m_articleId);
        or.setArticleText("Text for " + m_articleId);
        or.setQuantity(m_quantity);
        m_orderRows.getItems().add(or);
        m_orderRows.deselectCurrentSelection();
        m_orderRows.selectItem(or);
        m_quantity = 1;
        m_articleId = "";
        m_soundTrigger.trigger();
    }
    
    public void onQuantityAction(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_articleIdFocus = RequestFocusManager.getNewRequestFocusCounter()+"";
    }
    
    public void onSetBarcodeFocus(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_articleIdFocus = RequestFocusManager.getNewRequestFocusCounter()+"";
    }

    protected String m_articleIdFocus = RequestFocusManager.getNewRequestFocusCounter()+"";
    public String getArticleIdFocus() { return m_articleIdFocus; }
    public void setArticleIdFocus(String value) { m_articleIdFocus = value; }

    protected String m_articleId;
    public String getArticleId() { return m_articleId; }
    public void setArticleId(String value) { m_articleId = value; }

}

System Tray (Java Client only)

By using component SYSTEMTRAY - typically inside your top page - a system tray icon is created.

Windows users: have a look onto the bottom right - this is the default location of your task bar's system tray icon region. There is one new icon when having opened this page - a person with blue shirt. When closing this page the icon will disappear.

The tray icon supports two commands: "hide" the whole client, and "show" the whole client. When hiding the client then the user will not even see the client in the operating system's task bar anymore. Hiding the application is useful when openeing the client and pushing it into some kind of "background" mode.

In addition the tray icon can display messages (also when the whole client is not visible), that can show certain information to the user which may trigger him/her to re-open the client. It's similar to the small info popups that you get from a mail client, once a mail has arrived inside your inbox.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:systemtray id="g_2" image="/images/icons/person.png" messagecontenttype="text/html" messagetext="#{d.DemoSystemTray.messageText}" messagetrigger="#{d.DemoSystemTray.messageTrigger}" text="This is a system tray." triggerhide="#{d.DemoSystemTray.triggerHide}" triggershow="#{d.DemoSystemTray.triggerShow}" >
<t:systemtraymenuitem id="g_3" actionListener="#{d.DemoSystemTray.onFirstMenuItem}" text="First Menu Item" />
<t:systemtraymenuitem id="g_4" actionListener="#{d.DemoSystemTray.onSecondMenuItem}" text="Second Menu Item" />
</t:systemtray>
<t:timer id="g_5" actionListener="#{d.DemoSystemTray.onCreateTrayMessage}" duration="#{d.DemoSystemTray.timerDuration}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_6" objectbinding="#{d.DemoSystemTray}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_7" >
<t:field id="g_8" text="#{d.DemoSystemTray.messageText}" width="100%" />
<t:coldistance id="g_9" width="10" />
<t:button id="g_10" actionListener="#{d.DemoSystemTray.onCreateTrayMessage}" text="Create Tray Message" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_11" height="20" />
<t:row id="g_12" >
<t:checkbox id="g_13" flush="true" selected="#{d.DemoSystemTray.timerActive}" text="One tray meesage every 5 seconds" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_14" height="20" />
<t:row id="g_15" >
<t:button id="g_16" actionListener="#{d.DemoSystemTray.onTriggerHide}" text="Hide Client" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.ModelessPopup;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.OKPopup;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.Statusbar;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.DefaultModelessPopupListener;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoSystemTray}")

public class DemoSystemTray
    extends PageBean
    implements Serializable
{
    public DemoSystemTray(IWorkpageDispatcher dispatcher)
    {
        super(dispatcher);
    }

    protected Trigger m_messageTrigger = new Trigger();
    Trigger m_triggerShow = new Trigger();
    Trigger m_triggerHide = new Trigger();
    protected String m_messageText;
    boolean m_timerActive = false;
    
    public String getMessageText() { return m_messageText; }
    public void setMessageText(String value) { m_messageText = value; }
    
    public boolean getTimerActive() { return m_timerActive; }
    public void setTimerActive(boolean timerActive) { m_timerActive = timerActive; }
    
    public Trigger getMessageTrigger() { return m_messageTrigger; }
    public Trigger getTriggerShow() { return m_triggerShow; }
    public Trigger getTriggerHide() { return m_triggerHide; }
    
    public int getTimerDuration()
    {
        if (m_timerActive == true)
            return 5000;
        else
            return 0;
    }

    public void onCreateTrayMessage(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_messageTrigger.trigger();
    }
    
    public void onTriggerHide(ActionEvent event)
    {
        m_triggerHide.trigger();
    }
    
    public void onFirstMenuItem(ActionEvent event)
    {
        Statusbar.outputSuccess("First Menu Item was clicked!");
    }

    public void onSecondMenuItem(ActionEvent event)
    {
        Statusbar.outputSuccess("Second Menu Item was clicked!");
    }

}

Window focus info (Java Client only)

The component WINDOWFOCUSINFO is a quite special one. It tells you with every roundtrip if the window, that is holding the component, has the focus (true) or not (false).

There are special use cases, in which this component makes sense: when e.g. retrieving an event from a serial scanner device (via CLIENTSERIALLRECEIVER or CLIENTDATAGRAMRECEIVER component) then you need to know, in which window the user currently works - so that your logic on server side can relate the event to the proper processing.

Please pay attention - the checkbox "My Window is active" seems to be "one step behin" always. But: the information about the window focus is passed always "with the next roundtrip" - so everything is fine!

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:clienthttpreceiver id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoWindowFocusInfo.onRefresh}" port="54321" />
<t:windowfocusinfo id="g_3" selected="#{d.DemoWindowFocusInfo.windowSelected}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_4" objectbinding="#{d.DemoWindowFocusInfo}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_5" >
<t:label id="g_6" text="My Window is active" width="150" />
<t:checkbox id="g_7" enabled="false" selected="#{d.DemoWindowFocusInfo.windowSelected}" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_8" height="20" />
<t:row id="g_9" >
<t:button id="g_10" actionListener="#{d.DemoWindowFocusInfo.onRefresh}" text="Refresh" />
<t:coldistance id="g_11" width="10" />
<t:button id="g_12" actionListener="#{d.DemoWindowFocusInfo.onOpenPopup}" text="Open Popup" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.ModelessPopup;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.Statusbar;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.DefaultModelessPopupListener;
import org.eclnt.util.log.CLog;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoWindowFocusInfo}")

public class DemoWindowFocusInfo
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    ModelessPopup m_modelessPopup;
    
    protected String m_windowSelected;
    protected boolean m_windowPopupSelected;
    
    public DemoWindowFocusInfo(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
    }
    
    public String getWindowSelected() { return m_windowSelected; }
    public void setWindowSelected(String value) 
    {
        CLog.L.log(CLog.LL_INF,"##### setWindowSelected: " + value);
        m_windowSelected = value; 
    }

    public boolean getWindowPopupSelected() { return m_windowPopupSelected; }
    public void setWindowPopupSelected(boolean value) 
    { 
        CLog.L.log(CLog.LL_INF,"##### setWindowPopupSelected: " + value);
        m_windowPopupSelected = value; 
    }

    public void onRefresh(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        Statusbar.outputMessage("Refresh was executed. " + System.currentTimeMillis());
    }
    
    public void onOpenPopup(ActionEvent event)
    {
        if (m_modelessPopup != null)
        {
            m_modelessPopup.requestFocus();
            return;
        }
        m_modelessPopup = getOwningDispatcher().createModelessPopup();
        m_modelessPopup.open
        (
                "/workplace/demowindowfocusinfopopup.jsp",
                "Hello!",
                800,
                600,
                new DefaultModelessPopupListener(m_modelessPopup)
                {
                    @Override
                    public void reactOnPopupClosedByUser()
                    {
                        super.reactOnPopupClosedByUser();
                        m_modelessPopup = null;
                    }
                }
        );
    }

}

Automated File Transfer (Java Client only)

This page includes a CLIENTFILETRANSFER component.

Create the directory C:\temp\transfer and the directory c:\temp\transferbackup within your client file system.

Then copy files into the c:\temp\transfer directory.

The files will be picked, uploaded and removed afterwards.


The component observes a certain directory and checks the directory for new files regularly. New files are transferred to the server side. After successful transfer the files are removed from the client file system. - It is possible to define an additional backup directory, in which all transferred files are copied before being removed.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:clientfiletransfer id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoClientFileTransfer.onClientFileTransferAction}" asynchronousuploadurl="#{d.DemoClientFileTransfer.uploadURL}" createdirectories="false" darkupload="false" scanduration="5000" separatebackupdirectories="true" transferbackupdirectory="c:\temp\transferbackup" transferdirectory="c:\temp\transfer" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" objectbinding="#{d.DemoClientFileTransfer}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:textarea id="g_5" height="100%" text="#{d.DemoClientFileTransfer.protocol}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;
import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.bufferedcontent.DefaultUploadContent;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.bufferedcontent.UploadContentMgr;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.Statusbar;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;
import org.eclnt.workplace.WorkpageDefaultLifecycleListener;
import org.eclnt.workplace.WorkpageDispatchedBean;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoClientFileTransfer}")

public class DemoClientFileTransfer
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    class UploadContent extends DefaultUploadContent
    {
        public void beginPassing()
        {
            m_protocol += "File Upload:\n"; 
        }
        public void passClientFile(String fileName, byte[] content)
        {
            m_protocol += fileName + ": " + content.length + "\n"; 
        }
        public void endPassing()
        {
            m_protocol += "\n"; 
        }
    }
    
    String m_protocol = "Copy any files into your client directory c:\\temp\\transfer - they will be automatically transferred to the server.\n\n";
    UploadContent m_uploadContent;
    
    public DemoClientFileTransfer(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
        m_uploadContent = new UploadContent();
        UploadContentMgr.add(m_uploadContent);
        getWorkpage().addLifecycleListener(new WorkpageDefaultLifecycleListener()
        {
            @Override
            public void reactOnDestroyed()
            {
                UploadContentMgr.remove(m_uploadContent);
            }
        });
    }
    
    public String getUploadURL() { return m_uploadContent.getURL(); }

    public String getProtocol() { return m_protocol; }
    public void setProtocol(String value) { this.m_protocol = value; }

    public void onClientFileTransferAction(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        Statusbar.outputSuccess("Client file transfer was finished. " + System.currentTimeMillis());
    }

}

Client System Properties (Java Client only)

The component SYSTEMPROPERTYREADER reads all system properties that are available on client side and sends these properties to the server. On server side they are transferred into the corresponding bean property that is bound via the attribute SYSTEMPROPERTYVALUE. The property value is sent exactly one time by the component.

The system property values are passed as semicolon separated String: <name>;<value>;<name>;<value;... - for decoding you should use the ValueManager.decodeCSV() function on server side.

In addition to the "normal" system properties, the following information is sent as well:

(.) Names of locally available printers, the corresponding names are "cc.localprinter.0", "cc.localprinter.1" etc.
(.) The client parameters that were used for starting the client. Each client parameter is prefixed with "cc.clientparameter."

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:systempropertyreader id="g_2" systempropertyvalue="#{d.DemoSystemPropertyReader.sysProps}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" objectbinding="#{d.DemoSystemPropertyReader}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:button id="g_5" actionListener="#{d.DemoSystemPropertyReader.onSynchronize}" text="Synchronize" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_6" height="10" />
<t:row id="g_7" >
<t:label id="g_8" text="&#34;Raw&#34; text" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_9" >
<t:textarea id="g_10" enabled="false" height="100%" text="#{d.DemoSystemPropertyReader.sysProps}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_11" >
<t:label id="g_12" text="&#34;Formatted&#34; text" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_13" >
<t:textarea id="g_14" enabled="false" height="100%" text="#{d.DemoSystemPropertyReader.formattedSysProps}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;
import java.util.List;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.util.valuemgmt.ValueManager;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;
import org.eclnt.workplace.WorkpageDispatchedBean;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoSystemPropertyReader}")

public class DemoSystemPropertyReader
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    String m_formattedSysProps;
    public String getFormattedSysProps() { return m_formattedSysProps; }
    public void setFormattedSysProps(String value) { this.m_formattedSysProps = value; }


    String m_sysProps;
    public String getSysProps() { return m_sysProps; }
    public void setSysProps(String value) { this.m_sysProps = value; }

    public DemoSystemPropertyReader(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
    }

    public void onSynchronize(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (m_sysProps != null)
        {
            StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
            String[] ls = ValueManager.decodeCSV(m_sysProps);
            for (int i=0; i<ls.length; i+=2)
            {
                sb.append(ls[i] + ":\n" + ls[i+1] + "\n\n");
            }
            m_formattedSysProps = sb.toString();
        }
    }
}

Client Monitoring Info (Java Client only)

The CLIENTMONITOR component sends basic monitoring information from the client to the server.

You may include this information inside your server side monitoring in order to compare server side performance figures with client side performance.

The information that is sent from the client side is always related to the previous roundtrip.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:clientmonitor id="g_2" value="#{d.DemoClientMonitor.monitorValue}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" objectbinding="#{d.DemoClientMonitor}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:icon id="g_5" actionListener="#{d.DemoClientMonitor.onRoundtripAction}" font="size:18" image="/images/icons/bigcalendar.png" text="Trigger roundtrip" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_6" >
<t:textarea id="g_7" height="100%" text="#{d.DemoClientMonitor.protocol}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;
import java.util.Map;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.util.valuemgmt.ValueManager;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;
import org.eclnt.workplace.WorkpageDispatchedPageBean;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoClientMonitor}")

public class DemoClientMonitor
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    public void onRoundtripAction(ActionEvent event) 
    {}

    String m_monitorValue;
    public String getMonitorValue() { return m_monitorValue; }
    public void setMonitorValue(String value) 
    { 
        m_monitorValue = value;
        Map<String,String> map = ValueManager.decodeComplexValue(value);
        m_protocol += "\n\nLast request: ";
        m_protocol += " roundtrip " + map.get("roundtrip") + " ms";
        m_protocol += "\nUI update " + map.get("uiupdate") + " ms";
        m_protocol += "\nFull information: " + value;
        // use ValueManager.decodeComplexValue(value) for transferring the 
        // string into a map
    }
    
    String m_protocol = "Protocol:";
    public String getProtocol() { return m_protocol; }
    

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // inner classes
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------


    /* Listener to the user of the page bean. */
    public interface IListener
    {
    }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    private IListener m_listener;

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoClientMonitor(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
    }

    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/democlientmonitor.jsp"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoClientMonitor}"; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    /* Initialization of the bean. Add any parameter that is required within your scenario. */
    public void prepare(IListener listener)
    {
        m_listener = listener;
    }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // private usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
}

Client Cookies

The component CLIENTCOOKIE stores and reads a string value within a client side cookie.

A cookie has a NAME-attribute. Please only use "proper variable names" without.

And a cookie has a VALUE-attribute. This attribute is used in two directions: if you change the value on server side, then the new value is written into the cookie on client side. And: if the component is started then the current content of the cookie is written into the VALUE - and it transfers the current client value from the client to the serve side.

Please note: there is a certain complexity involved in order to get the current cookie value of the client to the server side at startup point of time of the dialog:
The component transfers the cookie value with the next roundtrip from the client to the server side. So you have to trigger this roundtrip explicitly. The component to use is the component CALLSERVERONTRIGGER which executes one roundtrip when being triggered.

And please note: there is a component CLIENTLOCALSTORAGE doing exactly the same - but storing the data on client side in the local storage of the client.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:callserverontrigger id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoCookie.onRoundtripAction}" trigger="#{d.DemoCookie.roundtripTrigger}" />
<t:clientcookie id="g_3" name="test2" value="#{d.DemoCookie.cookieTest2Content}" />
<t:clientcookie id="g_4" name="test" value="#{d.DemoCookie.cookieTestContent}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_5" objectbinding="#{d.DemoCookie}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_6" >
<t:label id="g_7" text="Cookie &#34;test&#34;" width="100" />
<t:label id="g_8" text="#{d.DemoCookie.cookieTestContent}" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_9" >
<t:label id="g_10" text="Cookie &#34;test2&#34;" width="100" />
<t:label id="g_11" text="#{d.DemoCookie.cookieTest2Content}" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_12" height="60" />
<t:row id="g_13" >
<t:field id="g_14" labeltext="New test - content" text="#{d.DemoCookie.newContent}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_15" >
<t:field id="g_16" labeltext="test2 - content" text="#{d.DemoCookie.newContent2}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_17" >
<t:button id="g_18" actionListener="#{d.DemoCookie.onSetContent}" text="Set Content" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoCookie}")

public class DemoCookie
    extends PageBean
    implements Serializable
{
    Trigger m_roundtripTrigger = new Trigger();
    String m_newContent;
    String m_cookieTestContent;
    String m_cookieTest2Content;
    String m_newContent2;
    
    public DemoCookie(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);    
        // initiate one roundtrip through component CALLSERVERONTRIGGER
        // so that cookie value is immediately transferred at startup
        m_roundtripTrigger.trigger();
    }

    public Trigger getRoundtripTrigger() { return m_roundtripTrigger; }
    
    public String getCookieTestContent() { return m_cookieTestContent; }
    public void setCookieTestContent(String value) { m_cookieTestContent = value; }
    
    public String getNewContent() { return m_newContent; }
    public void setNewContent(String value) { this.m_newContent = value; }

    public String getCookieTest2Content() { return m_cookieTest2Content; }
    public void setCookieTest2Content(String value) { this.m_cookieTest2Content = value; }

    public String getNewContent2() { return m_newContent2; }
    public void setNewContent2(String value) { this.m_newContent2 = value; }

    public void onRoundtripAction(ActionEvent event)
    {
        // no action required - the roundtrip's purpose is to let the CLIENTCOOKIE
        // control pass the value.
    }
    
    public void onSetContent(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_cookieTestContent = m_newContent;
        m_cookieTest2Content = m_newContent2;
        m_newContent = null;
        m_newContent2 = null;
    }

}

Client Local Storage

The component CLIENTLOCALSTORAGE stores and reads a string value within the client side storage.

The client side storage is a name/value based storage - so you have to define the NAME attribute with the key you want to use to store data on client side.

The VALUE attribute is used in two directions: if you change the value on server side, then the new value is written into the storage on client side. And: if the component is started then the current content of the client storage is written into the VALUE.

Please note: there is a certain complexity involved in order to get the current client storage value to the server side at startup point of time of the dialog:
The component transfers the value with the next roundtrip from the client to the server side. So you have to trigger this roundtrip explicitly. The component to use is the component CALLSERVERONTRIGGER which executes one roundtrip when being triggered.

And please note: there is a component CLIENTCOOKIE doing exactly the same - but storing the value on client side as cookie.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:callserverontrigger id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoClientLocalStorage.onRoundtripAction}" trigger="#{d.DemoClientLocalStorage.roundtripTrigger}" />
<t:clientlocalstorage id="g_3" name="test" value="#{d.DemoClientLocalStorage.localStorageContent}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_4" objectbinding="#{d.DemoClientLocalStorage}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_5" >
<t:label id="g_6" text="Client local storage value" width="200" />
<t:label id="g_7" text="#{d.DemoClientLocalStorage.localStorageContent}" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_8" height="60" />
<t:row id="g_9" >
<t:label id="g_10" text="New Content" width="200" />
<t:field id="g_11" text="#{d.DemoClientLocalStorage.newContent}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_12" >
<t:coldistance id="g_13" width="200" />
<t:button id="g_14" actionListener="#{d.DemoClientLocalStorage.onSetContent}" text="Set Content" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoClientLocalStorage}")

public class DemoClientLocalStorage
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    Trigger m_roundtripTrigger = new Trigger();
    String m_newContent;
    String m_localStorageContent;

    public DemoClientLocalStorage(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher); 
        // initiate one roundtrip through component CALLSERVERONTRIGGER
        // so that cookie value is immediately transferred at startup
        m_roundtripTrigger.trigger();
    }

    public Trigger getRoundtripTrigger() { return m_roundtripTrigger; }
    
    public String getLocalStorageContent() { return m_localStorageContent; }
    public void setLocalStorageContent(String value) { m_localStorageContent = value; }
    
    public String getNewContent() { return m_newContent; }
    public void setNewContent(String value) { this.m_newContent = value; }

    public void onRoundtripAction(ActionEvent event)
    {
        // no action required - the roundtrip's purpose is to let the CLIENTCOOKIE
        // control pass the value.
    }
    
    public void onSetContent(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_localStorageContent = m_newContent;
        m_newContent = null;
    }

}

Client File API (Java Client only)

File Poller

The file poller is an invisible component that allows to establish a client side file interface for sending data to the server.

A certain directory (FILEDIRECTORY) is regularly scanned (SCANDURATION) for new files - either for all files of for files holding a certain extension (FILEEXTENSIONS).

When a new file is detected the component first renames it to, then calls the action listener and passes the name of the file and its content to the server side processing. In the server side action event you gain access to the data.

Please be aware of that there may be several files that are transferred via one action event! You need to scan through the whole list of strings that is provided by BaseActionEventClientFilePoll.getFileNamesAndContent in order to catch all files that were polled.

After the files are uploaded from client side, the files by default are removed. For monitoring reasons you may specify attribute POSTTRANSFERBEHAVIOR as "keep" - the renamed files will be kept in the same directory.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:clientfilepoller id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoFilePoller.onPollAction}" filedirectory="c:\temp\filepoller" posttransferbehavior="remove" scanduration="1000" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" objectbinding="#{d.DemoFilePoller}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:label id="g_5" text="Copy some files into the directory c:\temp\demofilepoller ..." />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_6" >
<t:textarea id="g_7" height="200" text="#{d.DemoFilePoller.pollInfo}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;
import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.events.BaseActionEventClientFilePoll;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;
import org.eclnt.workplace.WorkpageDispatchedBean;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoFilePoller}")

public class DemoFilePoller
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    String m_pollInfo;
    public DemoFilePoller(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
        m_pollInfo = "<no poll action yet>";
    }
    
    public String getPollInfo() { return m_pollInfo; }
    public void setPollInfo(String value) { this.m_pollInfo = value; }

    public void onPollAction(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (event instanceof BaseActionEventClientFilePoll)
        {
            StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
            BaseActionEventClientFilePoll e = (BaseActionEventClientFilePoll)event;
            String[] infos = e.getFileNamesAndContent();
            for (int i=0; i<infos.length; i+=2)
            {
                sb.append("\nFile name: " + infos[i]);
                sb.append("\nFile content length: " + infos[i+1].length()/2);
                sb.append("\n\n");
            }
            m_pollInfo = sb.toString();
        }
    }

}

File Pusher

The file pusher is an invisible component that allows to establish a client side file interface for sending data to the client.

When triggered (TRIGGER attribute) then the binary content contained in HEXCONTENT is transferred into the file that is defined by FILENAME. By default existing files are overwritten - when defining FILEOVERWRITE as false, the no overwriting will take place, in this case the attempt to write will just be ignored.

You can set attribute FILEREMOVEONDESTROY to "true" - in this case the file will be removed automatically on client side then the CLIENTFILEPUSHER component is destroyed. This happens when the (invisible) component is removed from the client side component tree (e.g. because it is part of an included page that is not shown anymore).

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:clientfilepusher id="g_2" filename="#{d.DemoFilePusher.fileName}" fileoverwrite="true" fileremoveondestroy="true" hexcontent="#{d.DemoFilePusher.fileContent}" trigger="#{d.DemoFilePusher.writeFileTrigger}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" objectbinding="#{d.DemoFilePusher}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:label id="g_5" text="File name" width="100" />
<t:field id="g_6" text="#{d.DemoFilePusher.fileName}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_7" >
<t:textarea id="g_8" height="200" text="#{d.DemoFilePusher.text}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_9" >
<t:button id="g_10" actionListener="#{d.DemoFilePusher.onTrigger}" text="Push Content to Client" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_11" height="30" />
<t:row id="g_12" >
<t:label id="g_13" text="Hex representation of file content" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_14" >
<t:textarea id="g_15" enabled="false" height="100" text="#{d.DemoFilePusher.fileContent}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.Statusbar;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.util.valuemgmt.ValueManager;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;
import org.eclnt.workplace.WorkpageDispatchedBean;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoFilePusher}")

public class DemoFilePusher
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    String m_fileName = "c:/temp/fromserver.txt";
    public String getFileName() { return m_fileName; }
    public void setFileName(String value) { this.m_fileName = value; }

    String m_text = "This is the text of the file to be created on client side.";
    public String getText() { return m_text; }
    public void setText(String value) { this.m_text = value; }

    Trigger m_writeFileTrigger = new Trigger();
    public Trigger getWriteFileTrigger() { return m_writeFileTrigger; }

    String m_fileContent;
    public String getFileContent() { return m_fileContent; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoFilePusher(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
    }

    public void onTrigger(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        try
        {
            byte[] bytes = m_text.getBytes("UTF-8");
            m_fileContent = ValueManager.encodeHexString(bytes);
            m_writeFileTrigger.trigger();
        }
        catch (Throwable t)
        {
            Statusbar.outputError(t.toString(),ValueManager.getStackstraceString(t));
        }
    }

}

USB File Reader

If triggered, the component scans all available client root directories and checks if a file with the name defined in FILENAMEINROOT exists.

If it exists then an event is sent to the server side - providing the full client name of the file and providing the content of the file.

If it does not exist then also an evnet is sent up to the server side, this time indicating that there is no corresponding file on client side.

Typical usage case: you want to check and read a certain file that resides on a USB stick (e.g. containing some certificate information). You do not know the drive name of the file, because this is dynamically assigned by the client operating system.

With ROOTSTOEXCLUDE you may optionally define roots in which you do not want to look for the file, e.g. you may exclude "C:\;D:\" in order bypass the client side hard disk. You may also pass a ROOTSTOPREFER value, a semicolon separated list of roots, that the component should check first for the file. This makes sense, if your USB sticks always are bound to a certain drive letter.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:clientusbfilereader id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoClientUsbFileReader.onClientUsbFileAction}" filenameinroot="#{d.DemoClientUsbFileReader.filenameInRoot}" rootstoprefer="f:&#92;;x:&#92;" trigger="#{d.DemoClientUsbFileReader.trigger}" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" objectbinding="#{d.DemoClientUsbFileReader}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:label id="g_5" text="Filename in Root" width="100" />
<t:field id="g_6" text="#{d.DemoClientUsbFileReader.filenameInRoot}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_7" >
<t:coldistance id="g_8" width="100" />
<t:button id="g_9" actionListener="#{d.DemoClientUsbFileReader.onTriggerUsbFileRead}" text="Check for Client USB File" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_10" height="59" />
<t:row id="g_11" >
<t:label id="g_12" text="Result" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_13" >
<t:textarea id="g_14" height="100%" text="#{d.DemoClientUsbFileReader.result}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.events.BaseActionEventClientUsbFileReader;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;
import org.eclnt.workplace.WorkpageDispatchedBean;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoClientUsbFileReader}")

public class DemoClientUsbFileReader
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    String m_filenameInRoot = "temp/test.png";
    public String getFilenameInRoot() { return m_filenameInRoot; }
    public void setFilenameInRoot(String value) { this.m_filenameInRoot = value; }

    Trigger m_trigger = new Trigger();
    public Trigger getTrigger() { return m_trigger; }
    public void setTrigger(Trigger value) { this.m_trigger = value; }

    String m_result;
    public String getResult() { return m_result; }
    public void setResult(String value) { this.m_result = value; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoClientUsbFileReader(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
    }

    public void onTriggerUsbFileRead(ActionEvent event)
    {
        m_trigger.trigger();
    }
    
    public void onClientUsbFileAction(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (event instanceof BaseActionEventClientUsbFileReader)
        {
            BaseActionEventClientUsbFileReader e = (BaseActionEventClientUsbFileReader)event;
            if (e.getFileFound() == true)
            {
                StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
                sb.append("File was found on client side." +
                          "\n\nClient file name: " +
                          e.getClientFileName() + 
                          "\n\nContent:\n" +
                          e.getFileContentAsHexString());
                m_result = sb.toString();
            }
            else
            {
                StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
                sb.append("File was NOT found on client side."); 
                m_result = sb.toString();
            }
        }
    }

}

Subpage - one CC page within another

A CaptainCasa dialog can be embedded either by using the general BROWSER components - or by using the SUBPAGE component.

In the SUBPAGE component you directly pass the URL of the layout definition that you want to embed.

The embedding of the page is done using the HTML-iframe element. Please pay attention: some configuration is required to embed pages that are not loaded from the same origin (protocol + server + port) than the outside page. Please check the document "CaptainCasa Security Guide", section "Content Security Protocol / CSP".

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_1" objectbinding="#{d.DemoSubpage}" rowdistance="10" >
<t:row id="g_2" coldistance="5" >
<t:combobox id="g_4" editable="true" labeltext="Layout URL of contained sub-page" validvaluesbinding="#{d.DemoSubpage.subpageURLVVS}" value="#{d.DemoSubpage.subpageURL}" width="100%" />
<t:button id="g_5" text="Show" width="100+" />
</t:row>
<t:rowdistance id="g_7" height="30" />
<t:row id="g_15" >
<t:label id="g_6" stylevariant="ccbig" text="Embedded layout" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_17" >
<t:textpane id="g_18" font="weight:normal" stylevariant="ccsmall" text="The result might not be shown due to security settings or non-availability of servers behind the selected URL!" width="100%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_10" >
<t:subpage id="g_11" height="100%" subpagesessionid="#{d.DemoSubpage.subPageSessionId}" url="#{d.DemoSubpage.subpageURL}" width="100%" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.ValidValuesBinding;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.util.HttpSessionAccess;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoSubpage}")

public class DemoSubpage
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // inner classes
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    static final String PORT = "50000"; 
    ValidValuesBinding m_subpageURLVVS = new ValidValuesBinding();
    String m_subpageURL;

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoSubpage(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);
        if (HttpSessionAccess.checkIfCurrentClientJavaTypeIsRisc())
            this.m_subpageURL = "http://localhost:"+PORT+"/demos/faces/workplace/demohelloworld.jsp";
        else if (HttpSessionAccess.checkIfCurrentClientJavaTypeIsFX())
            this.m_subpageURL = "http://localhost:"+PORT+"/demos/faces/workplace/demohelloworld.jsp?ccstyle=ccmetrofx";
        else if (HttpSessionAccess.checkIfCurrentClientJavaTypeIsSwing())
            this.m_subpageURL = "http://localhost:"+PORT+"/demos/faces/workplace/demohelloworld.jsp?ccstyle=default";
        m_subpageURLVVS.addValidValue(this.m_subpageURL,this.m_subpageURL);
        m_subpageURLVVS.addValidValue("http://www.captaincasa.online/ccdemos/faces/workplace/demohelloworld.jsp",
                                      "http://www.captaincasa.online/ccdemos/faces/workplace/demohelloworld.jsp");
        m_subpageURLVVS.addValidValue("https://www.captaincasa.online/ccdemos/faces/workplace/demohelloworld.jsp",
                                      "https://www.captaincasa.online/ccdemos/faces/workplace/demohelloworld.jsp");
    }

    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/demosubpage.jsp"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoSubpage}"; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public ValidValuesBinding getSubpageURLVVS() { return m_subpageURLVVS; }

    public String getSubpageURL() { return m_subpageURL; }
    public void setSubpageURL(String value) { this.m_subpageURL = value; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // private usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
}

JavaScript Method Caller

The invisible component CLIENTJSMETHODCALLER calls a JavaScript method on client side.

The attribute JSCALL contains the JavaScript call of the method. Pleas note - you may only pass one JavaScript call - so you cannot pass a sequence of statements.

Dependent on the attribute WITHCALLBACK the result of the calls is transferred back to the server.

All parameters are interpreted as String parameters - both the parameters you pass into the JavaScript statement and the parameter that you return as result (if having set WITHCALLBACK to true).

In the RISC client you may add JavaScript libraries using system.xml configuration file ():

<system...>
...
<riscclientscript src="xxx.js" type="text/javascript"/>
...
</system>

In the JavaSwing client you may add JavaScript processing by simply updating the .html file in which the client-applet is embedded.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:beanprocessing id="g_1" >
<t:clientjsmethodcaller id="g_2" actionListener="#{d.DemoClientJSMethodCaller.onJsCallAction}" jscall="#{d.DemoClientJSMethodCaller.jsCall}" trigger="#{d.DemoClientJSMethodCaller.trigger}" withcallback="true" />
</t:beanprocessing>
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_3" objectbinding="#{d.DemoClientJSMethodCaller}" rowdistance="#{ccstylevalue['@defaultrowdistance@']}" >
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:label id="g_5" text="First Parameter" width="150" />
<t:field id="g_6" text="#{d.DemoClientJSMethodCaller.p1}" width="100" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_7" >
<t:label id="g_8" text="Second Parameter" width="150" />
<t:field id="g_9" text="#{d.DemoClientJSMethodCaller.p2}" width="100" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_10" >
<t:coldistance id="g_11" width="150" />
<t:button id="g_12" actionListener="#{d.DemoClientJSMethodCaller.onTriggerAction}" text="Trigger" />
<t:coldistance id="g_13" width="10" />
<t:label id="g_14" text="#{d.DemoClientJSMethodCaller.jsCall}" />
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import javax.faces.event.ActionEvent;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.defaultscreens.Statusbar;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.events.BaseActionEventJsCallResult;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.pagebean.PageBean;
import org.eclnt.util.valuemgmt.ValueManager;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoClientJSMethodCaller}")

public class DemoClientJSMethodCaller
    extends PageBean
    implements Serializable
{
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // inner classes
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // members
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
    Trigger m_trigger = new Trigger();
    String m_jsCall = "";
    String m_p1 = "Captain";
    String m_p2 = "Casa";
    
    
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // constructors & initialization
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public DemoClientJSMethodCaller(IWorkpageDispatcher dispatcher)
    {
        super(dispatcher);
    }
    
    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/democlientjsmethodcaller.jsp"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoClientJSMethodCaller}"; }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // public usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------

    public String getJsCall() { return m_jsCall; }
    public void setJsCall(String value) { this.m_jsCall = value; }

    public Trigger getTrigger() { return m_trigger; }
    public void setTrigger(Trigger value) { this.m_trigger = value; }

    public void onTriggerAction(ActionEvent event)
    {
        // the concatenation via encodeMethod is important - because it
        // properly encodes "," characters within the parameters!
        m_jsCall = ValueManager.encodeMethod("testJSMethodCall",new String[] 
        {
            m_p1,
            m_p2
        });
        m_trigger.trigger();
    }

    public String getP2() { return m_p2; }
    public void setP2(String value) { this.m_p2 = value; }

    public String getP1() { return m_p1; }
    public void setP1(String value) { this.m_p1 = value; }

    public void onJsCallAction(ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (event instanceof BaseActionEventJsCallResult)
        {
            BaseActionEventJsCallResult e = (BaseActionEventJsCallResult)event;
            if (e.getSuccess() == true)
                Statusbar.outputSuccess("Result of call: " + e.getSuccess() + ", " + e.getResult());
            else
                Statusbar.outputError("Result of call: " + e.getSuccess() + ", " + e.getResult());
        }
    }

    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    // private usage
    // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
}

RISC Client Integration

Camera / take photo

The CAMERA component shows what is currently is recorded by the web camera. By pressing the "snap"-button, the current image is sent to the server side in its original camera resolution.

The CAMERA component requires some explicit activation by the user for security reasons. It is NOT available on Internet Explorer 10/11.

This is the XML layout definition:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<t:layoutdefinition xmlns:t="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/t" xmlns:tpbc="http://www.CaptainCasa.com/controllibrary/tpbc" >
<t:rowdemobodypane id="g_1" objectbinding="#{d.DemoCamera}" rowdistance="10" >
<t:row id="g_2" >
<t:camera id="g_3" actionListener="#{d.DemoCamera.onCameraAction}" devicesorting="environment" height="100%" width="100%" trigger="#{d.DemoCamera.trigger}" withsnapicon="#{d.DemoCamera.withSnapIcon}" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_4" >
<t:foldablepane id="g_5" text="Capturing" width="100%" >
<t:row id="g_6" >
<t:checkbox id="g_7" flush="true" selected="#{d.DemoCamera.withSnapIcon}" text="With snap icon" />
<t:coldistance id="g_8" width="100%" />
<t:button id="g_9" actionListener="#{d.DemoCamera.onTriggerSnapAction}" text="Take photo via button" width="100+" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_10" >
<t:coldistance id="g_11" width="50%" />
<t:label id="g_12" text="Captured image" />
<t:coldistance id="g_13" width="50%" />
</t:row>
<t:row id="g_14" >
<t:coldistance id="g_15" width="50%" />
<t:image id="g_16" height="100" image="#{d.DemoCamera.capturedImageURL}" width="100" />
<t:coldistance id="g_17" width="50%" />
</t:row>
</t:foldablepane>
</t:row>
</t:rowdemobodypane>
<t:pageaddons id="g_pa"/>
</t:layoutdefinition>

This is the Java code:

package workplace;

import java.io.Serializable;

import org.eclnt.editor.annotations.CCGenClass;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.events.BaseActionEventCameraSnap;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.elements.util.Trigger;
import org.eclnt.jsfserver.util.tempfile.TempFileManager;
import org.eclnt.workplace.IWorkpageDispatcher;

@CCGenClass (expressionBase="#{d.DemoCamera}")

public class DemoCamera
    extends PageBean 
    implements Serializable
{
    boolean m_withSnapIcon = true;
    public boolean getWithSnapIcon() { return m_withSnapIcon; }
    public void setWithSnapIcon(boolean value) { this.m_withSnapIcon = value; }

    public void onTriggerSnapAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        m_trigger.trigger();
    }

    Trigger m_trigger = new Trigger();
    public Trigger getTrigger() { return m_trigger; }

    String m_capturedImageURL = null;
    
    public DemoCamera(IWorkpageDispatcher workpageDispatcher)
    {
        super(workpageDispatcher);        
    }

    public String getPageName() { return "/workplace/democamera.jsp"; }
    public String getRootExpressionUsedInPage() { return "#{d.DemoCamera}"; }

    public String getCapturedImageURL() { return m_capturedImageURL; }

    public void onCameraAction(javax.faces.event.ActionEvent event) 
    {
        if (event instanceof BaseActionEventCameraSnap)
        {
            BaseActionEventCameraSnap e = (BaseActionEventCameraSnap)event;
            byte[] bytes = e.getPNGImageBytes();
            m_capturedImageURL = TempFileManager.saveTempFile("capturedImage.png",bytes);
        }
    }
}

Geo location

The component GEOLOCATION transfers the current GPS position of the device to the server side. Whenever the GPS location changes a corresponding signal is sent to the server side.

With the attribute SCANDELAY you can limit the frequency of sending updated positions: if e.g. the value is set to 10000 (10 seconds) then there will be a maximum frequency of one message every 10 seconds.
